key_points: The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts
In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days
Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC
learning.explanation: The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav database is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports (position, ICAO identifier, elevation, etc.) Navaids (identifiers, frequencies, positions, types of aid, etc.) Airways (airway designator, outboard magnetic course, etc.) Waypoints (ICAO identifier, type, etc.) Runways (number, ICAO identifier, heading, length, etc.) Airport Procedures (SID, STARS, approach procedures, etc.) Magnetic variation Company routes (route number, origin, and destination airport, etc.) Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

learning.explanation: For aircraft designed to be operated by two pilots, two FMS units are usually installed. Usually, both systems are working independently from one another. Each of these systems consists of a separate flight management computer (FMC) as its core piece, and its own input/output device, the CDU or MCDU. The primary function of the CDU is to act as the interface between the aircraft and the crew. The CDU can be used to command completely automatic control of the aircraft or semi-automatic with varying degrees of pilot involvement including full manual control. An alpha/numeric CRT screen dominates the upper part of the unit, while the lower part has a keyboard. Using the keyboard, the flight crew can enter the desired vertical and lateral flight plan data into the Flight Management Computer.

key_points: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database
The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines
This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database. The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines. This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands. Additionally, the relevant data can be displayed and this reduces the need for the flight crew to refer to a performance manual during flight. The data stored includes: - aeroplane drag characteristics aeroplane drag characteristics - engine performance characteristics - maximum, optimum, minimum altitudes - speeds and speed limits - speed and altitude capability with one engine inoperative engine performance characteristics The maintenance group for individual aeroplanes can refine this data, by entering correction factors for drag and fuel flow, which are retained in the NV RAM for continued use.

content.question: What does the pilot need to do regarding the performance database in the FMC before taking off?

options.A: Enter the correct number index of load sheet.
options.B: Download to maintenance staff and erase it.
options.C: Nothing needs to be done by the pilot.
options.D: Check that it is up to date.

key_points: Performance data for the aircraft and its engines are stored in the aircraft’s database, performance database to be precise

In order for the FMS to make correct predictions, it is vital that the aircraft performance database contains correct data – calculations based on incorrect data will result in false computations and may be a threat to flight safety
Performance databases are based on the aircraft type, model, and engines fitted
learning.explanation: Performance data for the aircraft and its engines are stored in the aircraft’s database, performance database to be precise. In order for the FMS to make correct predictions, it is vital that the aircraft performance database contains correct data – calculations based on incorrect data will result in false computations and may be a threat to flight safety. Performance databases are based on the aircraft type, model, and engines fitted. This is why they do not go "out of date" like a navigation database does. The pilot must input the correct information from the load sheet and OFP (Operational Flight Plan) into the database before flight, which includes weights, centre of gravity positions, fuel quantities, and the performance degradation figure. The performance degradation figure is a value to allows the aircraft FMS (Flight Management System) to account for the increased drag and fuel burn of an older airframe. Note: Current feedback gives the "up to date" answer as correct. We believe that this should not be correct, and we think there may be some confusion possible between similar questions, some of which are talking about the navigation database rather than the performance database. We are therefore looking for any feedback (specifically about the wording of the question), so please put as much detail as you can remember in the comments or email it to info@atplquestions.com, thank you very much.

key_points: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory

The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing the following major functions: Aid for fuel management - improve fuel efficiency and performance optimization: The FMS has the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration
This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions
learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing the following major functions: Aid for fuel management - improve fuel efficiency and performance optimization: The FMS has the ability to provide correct fuel computations even in engine-out configuration. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions. Aid with navigation - lateral and vertical flight plan management: The FMS calculates the aircraft trajectory so that it respects any inserted constraints (altitude, speed, distance, etc. Aircraft position computation - The FMS computed position along the flight plan is derived from the data provided by the IRS, DME, VOR, and GPS. A monitoring section is provided in the MCDU where you can actually check the accuracy and integrity of the GPS signal and select the desired position computation method. Autotuning - automatic tuning of the radio navigation frequencies. The autotuning function automatically tunes the radio navigation facilities based on the available signals in terms of geometry and strength. Workload is greatly reduced because the flight crew only need to cross-check with their charts that the correct frequencies are automatically inserted.

key_points: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage
The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc
they might need along their route
learning.explanation: It shows the interface of an A320 FMS, including supplemental navigation data insertion and storage. The navigation database cannot be modified; however, it has some additional storage space where the flight crew can create and store additional waypoints, routes, navaids, etc. they might need along their route. An example of an additional waypoint could be some Decision Points, which coordinates are indicated in the Operational Flight Plan the crew receives during the briefing. On a several sectors day, it is very common that the pilot stores the flight back (the second sector) on this additional storage of the navigation database. For instance, the FMS2 Honeywell Release 1A, allows the flight crew to create and store up to 99 waypoints, 10 runways, 20 navaids, and 5 routes. This will be different from one FMS to another, but it already gives you an idea of the capability of the additional storage space of the navigation database, called the supplemental navigation database. Caution! It is really important to understand and make the difference that pilots can use the Supplemental Navigation database to write and read information => by adding their own customized waypoint or other navigation data. BUT this is limited to ONLY this Supplemental Nav database! At the time of the Main Nav database update (every 28 days) the Supp Nav database is automatically erased. It makes sense as the Supp Nav database could include waypoints that have been defined using waypoints contained in the Main Nav database that may have changed as a result of the update.

Usually, when this happens, the system will automatically deselect that GPS source and use only the valid ones.

key_points: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link
These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC)

The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link. These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. The second is the model and engine performance database and contains all the aircraft performance data which allows the FMC to compute fuel burn, optimum altitudes and airspeeds, etc. The third is the Navigation Database (NDB). Navigation Database contains : Airports Navaids (including their frequencies) Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Holding patterns Company flight plan routes Performance Database contains: V1, VR, V2 speeds, Aircraft drag curve characteristics, Engine thrust characteristics, Maximum and optimum operating altitude parameters, Optimum speeds for climb, cruise, descent, holding, etc. Fuel flow parameters under various flight conditions, Aircraft flight envelope, incl. maximum masses, etc.

An aircraft is equipped with a dual FMS configuration. The Pilot Monitoring (PM) enters flight plan data through his/her Multifunction Control and Display Unit (MCDU). Soon after, the crew realises that those data are NOT shown on the cross-side MCDU, and the PM reads an alerting message concerning the operational mode of the FMSs.
The FMS operate in (1) _____ mode, there is a problem with data transferring over the (2) _____ bus, and each MCDU communicates only with the (3) _____ FMS.

options.A: (1) dual; (2) performance data; (3) cross-side
options.B: (1) independent; (2) navigation data; (3) cross-side
options.C: (1) single; (2) flight plan data; (3) on-side
options.D: (1) independent; (2) cross-talk; (3) on-side

key_points: Aircraft designed to be operated by two pilots usually incorporate two FMS units
In such cases, both systems work independently from each other
Each of these systems consists of a separate flight management computer (FMC) as its core piece, and its own input/output device, the CDU or MCDU
learning.explanation: Aircraft designed to be operated by two pilots usually incorporate two FMS units. In such cases, both systems work independently from each other. Each of these systems consists of a separate flight management computer (FMC) as its core piece, and its own input/output device, the CDU or MCDU. Both systems are usually interconnected in a way that allows pilot entries made in one system to be transferred to the other unit. If one unit fails, the other FMS unit can still operate in “independent mode”, which provides less precision. In this architecture (dual FMS), a malfunction of the cross-talk bus may occur, where both FMS units will continue fully operational, as they perform all computations based on separate data. However, automatic alerts in the event of deviations between both units can no longer be issued, meaning that pilots will have to verify correct functions themselves. The exchange function between both units is also lost, therefore entries have to be made to both systems separately.

key_points: TAS is calculated by the Air Data Computer (ADC)
TAT can be converted to the actual outside air temperature (OAT) considering the flight Mach number
Once OAT has been determined, it can be used to obtain TAS from the corrected values for static and total pressure
learning.explanation: TAS is calculated by the Air Data Computer (ADC). TAT can be converted to the actual outside air temperature (OAT) considering the flight Mach number. Once OAT has been determined, it can be used to obtain TAS from the corrected values for static and total pressure. TAS can then be used, for example, by the INS to determine the actual wind from heading, track and groundspeed.

content.question: The purpose of a performance database is…

options.B: To track the performance of the aircraft over time and make adjustments due to age and wear.
options.C: To adjust the route depending on the performance of the aircraft.
options.D: To monitor the performance of the crew.

key_points: The information stored in the FMC is called database
The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation
The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model and is used by the FMS, among others, to predict aircraft performance and fuel consumption
learning.explanation: The information stored in the FMC is called database. The database is divided into two major sections: One contains performance related information and the other contains information dealing with navigation. The Aircraft Performance database includes de Engine model, Aerodynamical model and Performance model and is used by the FMS, among others, to predict aircraft performance and fuel consumption. Stored data include: Aircraft drag and required thrust in all approved configurations Engine thrust depending on thrust setting and density altitude Fuel flow depending on thrust setting Performance factor. Before using any of the contents in the aircraft performance database, the pilot must verify that the database is up to date. Should they be false, the database cannot be used for computation. There is no option for the pilot to modify any parameters in the aircraft performance database, it must be done by an authorised mechanic. Maintenance can refine the database for each aircraft by entering factors for drag and fuel flow.

key_points: Area Navigation is a method of navigation that permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the limits of the capability of self-contained systems such as the IRS
The area navigation allows a better and more fluid air traffic flow by reducing the flight distances and ultimately the fuel consumption and flight times
It also allows reducing the use of the conventional ground radio navigation systems which require a lot of maintenance
learning.explanation: Area Navigation is a method of navigation that permits aircraft operation on any desired flight path within the limits of the capability of self-contained systems such as the IRS. The area navigation allows a better and more fluid air traffic flow by reducing the flight distances and ultimately the fuel consumption and flight times. It also allows reducing the use of the conventional ground radio navigation systems which require a lot of maintenance. learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. The Flight Management System helps to reduce the flight crew’s workload by providing several extremely useful functions. One of those functions is the aid for fuel management that helps improving fuel efficiency and in-flight performance. This function will basically make internal calculations based on the aircraft weight, its cruising level, and the actual and expected wind conditions en-route to estimate the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan. Most of the time this tool is very accurate, but the number of parameters influencing the fuel consumption makes it difficult to exactly predict the fuel consumption. key_points: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link
These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC)

The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance
learning.explanation: The Flight Management Systems (FMS) consists of navigation radio receivers; inertial reference systems; air data systems; navigation, flight and instrument displays; flight control systems; engine and fuel system; and data link. These subsystems are managed and processed by the Flight Management Computer (FMC). The FMC provides the primary navigation, flight planning, and optimized terminal routes and en route guidance for the aircraft and is typically comprised of interrelated functions such as navigation, flight planning, trajectory prediction, performance computations, and guidance. The FMC and associated databases are an essential part of modern airline avionics. An FMC typically contains three databases in addition to the basic operational flight program (OFP). The first is a software options database which activates the optional functionality contained in the OFP that is desired by the operator. The second is the model and engine performance database and contains all the aircraft performance data which allows the FMC to compute fuel burn, optimum altitudes and airspeeds, etc. The third is the navigation database (NDB). The NDB contains all the information required for building a flight plan and processing that plan when airborne. All these databases are stored in the FMC on an electrically erasable programmable read-only memory (EEPROM) card. Each of these databases can be updated via a data loader. The NDB contains terminal and en route fixes; waypoints and navigation reference system (NRS) grid points; intersections; airways and radio navigation aids. It also contains airports; runways; STAR and SID; holding patterns; and instrument approaches such as VOR, non-directional beacon, area navigation (RNAV), required navigation performance (RNP), satellite based navigation system (SBAS), and ground based navigation system (GBAS). Note: Additional space is provided between the NDB to save navigational data created by the pilot

learning.explanation: FMS setup - Initial actions IDENT Page. Upon application of power to the aircraft, the FMS immediately executes a self-test procedure. Once this self-test is successfully completed, the IDENT page will be displayed. In the IDEN page, the crew can confirm the aircraft details on start-up and confirmation of the navigation database in operation will be presented. POS INIT Page. After the IDENT page, we will be directed to the POS INIT page where we will be presented with the following information: IRS Position Reference, IRS Heading Reference, GMT / UTC / Time Zone Display. We may then expect to enter our flight number details and identify a “standard” company route to take us to our destination. PERF INIT Page. Finally, we will move on to the PERF INIT page to update the aircraft to its current performance / weight configuration for the route to be flown.

learning.explanation: The FMS is responsible for computing and generating various flight management data, including flight plans, navigation, performance, and fuel calculations. The (M)CDU provides the interface for pilots to input and manage data related to the flight plan, performance, and other functions. Modern aircraft are designed to maximize redundancy and minimize inconvenience. In the event of a failure of one (M)CDU, the other (M)CDUs can be used to communicate with either or both FMSs in dual mode. Bottom line is: In the event of a single FMS failure, the second system can operate the aircraft successfully in single mode, which will also activate automatically if the cross-talk bus connecting the FMSs in dual mode fails. However, if only a (M)CDU fails, the system can still remain in dual mode, but monitoring the system and making changes to the flight path would only be possible through the functional (M)CDU.

options.C: It is manually entered by the pilots, based on the latest information available.

key_points: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required
Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them
FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds
learning.explanation: Navigation Display (ND) shows ‘instant’ wind velocity based upon on board computations are now quite accurate when instant variation is not required. Updating of on-board readouts of wind velocity depends on the system which generates them. FMS wind is the most accurate, because it is based upon changes of GPS or DME/DME position, but it may only be re-calculated every 30 seconds. The FMC (Flight Management Computer) is the box that calculates the wind. The inputs are: Track, heading and groundspeed from the nav system (varies between models, but typically inertial with updates from GPS and terrestrial navaids); and TAS from the ADC (Air Data Computer) The FMS solves for the final side of the vector triangle and computes wind (side 1- HDG/TAS; side 2- TRK/GS; side 3- Wind direction/magnitude). In a perfect world, the difference between TRK/GS and HDG/TAS is actual wind (direction, magnitude).

options.A: aeroplane performance and fuel saving.
options.B: aeroplane performance and navigation.
options.C: navigation and meteorology.
options.D: inertial and navigation.

key_points: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative
The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path
The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow
learning.explanation: The performance and navigation databases are two necessary components for the FMC to be operative. The performance database includes aircraft drag and engine parameters that the FMC will use to provide estimated fuel predictions and an optimized flight path. The maintenance can apply corrections to the current database by applying an engine coefficient that will modify the drag and the fuel flow. The navigation database of the FMC contains all the information that would normally be obtained from the navigation charts. In each aircraft, the FMC has two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days. Each of them conforms to a revision cycle that the crew will check and select during the cockpit preparation, usually done by the pilot flying who sets up the FMC. The nav database is updated by maintenance every 28 days. It includes the following data: Airports Navaids Airways Waypoints Runways SID, STARS, and approach procedures Magnetic variation. Note: The obstacles and terrain are not part of the FMS navigation database. They can only be found in the EGPWS database.

options.C: Will be announced by the FMS as WRONG DATABASE VERSION so that the pilot can correct the situation.

In the best case, it could produce a flight discontinuity if a waypoint or airway has changed, and the FMS is not able to guide the aircraft along the entered route

learning.explanation: The use of a new, not-yet valid database could be a threat to flight safety. However, it is possible that the FMS continues to follow a flight plan, but the aircraft will take a path that is unexpected to the pilots and ATC. Remember that if there are changes to routes, SIDS, STARS or waypoints, the changes are only effective after midnight UTC on the nominated date.

content.question: While preparing the cockpit, the pilot initiated the route loading process into the Flight Management System (FMS). Due to a distraction, the pilot inadvertently replaced the current navigation database with a newer version before its designated activation date. Is this problematic, and if so, why?

options.A: It can be an issue because certain waypoints and airways might have changed their coordinates, and the aircraft will follow an incorrect routing.
options.B: It is not a problem if the captain’s FMS still has the old (correct) database.
options.C: It is an issue because the pilot will need to load the flight plan again.
options.D: It is a problem, and you will probably get a warning.

key_points: Learning Objectives 022
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 022.11.02.01.05: Explain the threats and implications to the pilot of changing the database by error either on the ground or while flying. The Flight Management Computer (FMC) holds two sets of navigation data, each valid for 28 days to align with the standard revision cycle for navigation charts. Prior to flight, the flight crew can designate the active set, which the FMC employs for navigation computations. The maintenance department updates the contents of these navigation databases every 28 days. By the time the navigation chart revision date arrives, the new data is already integrated into the FMC and available for selection. Should pilots mistakenly switch navigation databases while on the ground or in-flight, it could compromise elements of the planned flight route, potentially leading to hazardous deviations in performance and navigation. In the best case, such an error may result in a flight plan discontinuity - this is typically flagged by multiple FMS warnings. However, there's also the possibility that the FMS can still adhere to the flight plan, albeit leading the aircraft along an unexpected path, causing both pilots and Air Traffic Control (ATC) personnel to lose situational awareness. This scenario could potentially result in perilous close encounters between aircraft.

learning.explanation: The Flight Management Computer (FMC) contains storage space for two databases, the Performance Database and the Navigation Database. The Performance Database contains an average model of the aeroplane and its engines. This model provides the FMC with the data required to calculate pitch and thrust commands. Additionally, the relevant data can be displayed and this reduces the need for the flight crew to refer to a performance manual during flight. The data stored includes: - aeroplane drag characteristics aeroplane drag characteristics - engine performance characteristics - maximum, optimum, minimum altitudes - speeds and speed limits - speed and altitude capability with one engine inoperative engine performance characteristics Generally, in the cockpit preparation phase and before starting to program the FMGS, the pilots will check both databases. The performance database is checked by confirming the Engine and Aircraft type as well as the performance factor. The navigation database validity is checked by confirming the current day is within the validity interval. content.question: Which of the following statements regarding the "performance factor" is correct? It is a…

options.A: cost index used to show the efficiency of the aircraft as a percentage of the nominal performance.
options.B: positive or negative factor that is used to correct the predicted fuel flow.
options.C: positive or negative factor that is used to calculate the percentage error in fuel consumption due to differences between nominal and icing conditions.
options.D: positive factor that is used to show the percentage increase in fuel consumption when there is an abnormal increase in drag.

key_points: Performance factor is obtained from the aircraft performance monitoring program every airplane from an operator’s given fleet is subject to
This index can be found on the operational flight plan provided to the flight crew before each flight so that it is crosschecked and corrected if it differs from the FMS
In fact, this factor is very important because it is used during the flight planning stage of the flight and it is a reference for the FMGS to maximize fuel economy on each and every sector
learning.explanation: Performance factor is obtained from the aircraft performance monitoring program every airplane from an operator’s given fleet is subject to. This index can be found on the operational flight plan provided to the flight crew before each flight so that it is crosschecked and corrected if it differs from the FMS. In fact, this factor is very important because it is used during the flight planning stage of the flight and it is a reference for the FMGS to maximize fuel economy on each and every sector. The performance factor will ‘guide’ the FMS to provide the optimum speeds, profiles, cruise levels, for better fuel predictions and more accurate managed operation information. In order to increase the fuel savings, the performance factor will help to correct the predicted fuel flow when the actual aircraft drag, and engine performance differs from the nominal model due to the aircraft’s age. On the Airbus A320, you can find the performance factor on the ‘A/C STATUS’ page after selecting the DATA selector key on the MCDU. The performance factor is situated right next to the idle factor and can either be positive or negative.

content.question: Which system is required in order for the FMS to control vertical navigation?

options.A: Pitch Controller
options.B: Autothrottle
options.C: Electronic Flight Bag
options.D: Flight Director

Therefore, in order to let the FMS to conducting all the vertical navigation, your aircraft definitely needs an autothrottle system
learning.explanation: It is true that there’re aircraft capable of controlling the vertical navigation without the autothrottle system. However, in this case the vertical navigation is not controlled by the FMS ONLY, but also by the pilot as he/she will act on the throttle levers. Therefore, in order to let the FMS to conducting all the vertical navigation, your aircraft definitely needs an autothrottle system. On a large commercial aircraft, the auto-throttle system usually has the following modes of operation: SPEED/MACH mode (holding of IAS/Mach number) and THRUST mode (N1 or EPR hold). In fact, the autopilot pitch channel and the auto-throttle system work together. The operating mode of one will determine the operating mode of the other. Find in this table, the summary of the autothrottle modes of operation and the respective flight phase: Flight phase Autothrottle mode Meaning Ground / TO roll N1 hold autothrottle commands full thrust for take-off. Climb IAS hold autothrottle commands full thrust for climb and the desired speed is maintained by the AP pitch channel. Climb with V/S IAS hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed. Cruise / ALT hold IAS/MACH hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed. Approach IAS hold autothrottle continuously regulates the thrust output to maintain the required speed.

content.question: In a dual FMS architecture, what happens if one of the FMS fails?

options.A: Pilots have to make an FMS reset as soon as possible.
options.B: If one FMS fails, the second will be lost as well.
options.C: The operative FMS will continue sending inputs to the failed FMS in order to recover it.
options.D: Redundancy is lost, the operative FMS will fully take over.

key_points: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions)
In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave
Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus
learning.explanation: The different modes of operation of the FMS are the following: Dual mode – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals.

com, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This question is based on unverified feedback. Please put any exam feedback in the comments, or email it to info@atplquestions.com, thank you. The FMS (Flight Management System) is the main computer that the pilots use to interface with the aircraft's more complex systems. Before a flight, the pilots will spend many minutes checking through the various pages in the FMS, making sure the data is correct, and inputting things such as the route, weights, clearances, temperatures, etc. The pilots can input many of these items from the OFP (Operational Flight Plan) which is part of the briefing pack the pilots have before the flight. Some of this data, however, such as updated weights and centre of gravity locations, arrive on the load sheet handed to the PIC by the dispatcher. The values on the load sheet then have to be checked/inputted into the FMS to make sure that the weights and CofG limits are correct for the flight. There are also databases in the FMS, and these are comprised of the navigation database and the performance database. These both need to be checked. The navigation database must be checked for time validity and the performance database must be checked to see if it contains the correct data, for example if it pertains to the correct aircraft variant with the correct engines. The alternate airport routing would not normally be entered into the FMS, unless it was expected to be used soon after take-off, which of course would be a scenario where taking off is not advisable in the first place. key_points: Navigation databases run in 28 day cycles, on the same dates as the AIRAC cycles, and it is a legal requirement for flying IFR to use the current navigation database (some procedures are allowed to be performed with an out-of-date database as long as differences are checked and it is less than 1 cycle out of date, but more on this in the annex above)

Almost all systems have an active and a standby database, where the standby database can be uploaded onto the avionics before change-over, and the data will change to the newer database automatically on the next startup of the avionics after the change-over, or updated manually by the pilots from standby to active
This makes it easier for engineers to be able to update the aircraft standby databases in the few days leading up to the change-over
learning.explanation: Navigation databases run in 28 day cycles, on the same dates as the AIRAC cycles, and it is a legal requirement for flying IFR to use the current navigation database (some procedures are allowed to be performed with an out-of-date database as long as differences are checked and it is less than 1 cycle out of date, but more on this in the annex above). Almost all systems have an active and a standby database, where the standby database can be uploaded onto the avionics before change-over, and the data will change to the newer database automatically on the next startup of the avionics after the change-over, or updated manually by the pilots from standby to active. learning.explanation: Some of the most sophisticated aircraft have complete dual FMS, two CDUs, and dula AFCS. A dual FMS system can be used in several ways: Dual mode (Master/Slave) – A modern commercial aircraft usually works in a dual FMS architecture (under normal conditions). In this mode, one FMC is always working as the master and the other as the slave. Both FMCs are synchronized, which means that each performs its own calculations then exchanges data with the other through a crosstalk bus. The master FMC sends its commands to the autopilot, the flight director system, and the autothrottle/collective. Independent mode – Both FMCs are decoupled and there’s ZERO cross-checking between them. This mode is automatically selected by the FMS under certain abnormal conditions such as different database validity on both FMCs. Single mode – When one FMC fails, the remaining one supplies both sides: its onside peripherals and failed FMC’s peripherals. Back-up - When the FMC has failed in certain areas, but still retains a limited FMS function.

learning.explanation: The core functionality of the Flight Management System (FMS) is the creation of a flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory. This greatly reduces the flight crew’s workload, especially under such stressful conditions. Aid with navigation - lateral and vertical flight plan management: The FMS calculates the aircraft trajectory so that it respects any inserted constraints (altitude, speed, distance, etc. Aircraft position computation: The FMS computed position along the flight plan is derived from the data provided by the IRS, DME, VOR, and GPS. learning.explanation: The Flight Management and Guidance System (FMGS) performs navigation functions and lateral and vertical flight planning functions. It also computes performance parameters and guides the aircraft along a preplanned route. The Flight Management (FM) part controls the following functions: - Navigation - Management of flight planning - Prediction and optimisation of performance - Management of navigation radios - Management of displays The Flight Management Computer (FMGC) computes its own aircraft position ('FM' position) from an IRS position and a computed radio position, or a GPS position. Each IRS computes a mixed IRS/GPS position called the GPIRS position. For this, each IRS can independently select their GPS source in order to maximize the availability of GPS data. If the GPIRS data does not comply with an integrity criterion that is based on a Horizontal Integrity Limit (HIL) and on the automatic detection of failed satellites, the FMS rejects the GPS mode and uses the radio position update. The flight crew can deselect/select the GPS position on the SELECTED NAVAIDS page, if necessary. Without GPS PRIMARY (GPS deselected or inoperative) the navigation accuracy is lower and is a function of ground radio navaid infrastructure or elapsed time since the last radio update. RNAV(GNSS) approaches may be performed, provided GPS PRIMARY is available and with AP or FD engaged. The flight crew may check the position computation using the POSITION MONITOR page.

key_points: Aircraft 1 (TCAS II) Aircraft 2 (TCAS II) TCAS II FUNCTIONS AVAILABLE Mode C or S Transponder INOP None – aircraft 2 is “invisible” Mode C or S Mode A Traffic Advisory (TA) only Mode C or S Mode C or S Traffic Advisory (TA) Resolution Advisory (RA) A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft
The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas
The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft
learning.explanation: Aircraft 1 (TCAS II) Aircraft 2 (TCAS II) TCAS II FUNCTIONS AVAILABLE Mode C or S Transponder INOP None – aircraft 2 is “invisible” Mode C or S Mode A Traffic Advisory (TA) only Mode C or S Mode C or S Traffic Advisory (TA) Resolution Advisory (RA) A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft. The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas. The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. Therefore, if other aircraft do not have a serviceable transponder no protection will be provided against them. In the same way, if any of the concerned aircraft does not have the altitude reporting capability from the mode C transponder, the TCAS II will only issue Traffic Advisories (TA). The TCAS computer uses the aircraft’s configuration data (gear/flaps), pressure altitude from the mode C transponder, and the radio altimeter’s height. The TCAS II has inputs from the radio altimeter in order to gradually inhibit the resolution advisories (RAs) when getting closer to the ground such as during the approach phase. The instrument itself can have a specifically dedicated screen situated on the cockpit’s instruments panel or it can be a variometer on a liquid crystal screen displaying the TAs and RAs. The TCAS II can also be integrated into an EFIS screen or be combined with the weather radar. The resolution advisories issued by the TCAS are either preventive or corrective: Preventive – advise the flight crew to monitor the vertical speed. Corrective – the vertical speed must be corrected without delay. The color and symbols code of the TCAS II is the following: Proximate traffic – white or cyan solid lozenge. Traffic advisory – amber solid circle. Resolution advisory – red full square.

learning.explanation: The first generation of GPWS consist of little more than a radar altimeter. learning.explanation: The EGPWS is an ENHANCED GPWS that has its own world terrain database. Therefore, if the aircraft experiences a position computation malfunction and is not accurate anymore, the terrain display will diverge from the real terrain environment around the aircraft position, and it will be erroneously indicated on the pilots’ Navigation Display (ND). The EGPWS may contain the following additional functions: Terrain Clearance Floor (TCF). Terrain Look Ahead function. Terrain Alerting and Display (TAD). The simple GPWS cannot detect a rising pick and provide useful and timely alerts since its measurements are based on the RA. However, the TCF function of the EGPWS contains an electronic map with all the obstacles and terrains giving the ground elevation, which means that the system can ‘see’ what obstacles are lying ahead of the aircraft = it has a ‘look-ahead’ capability. The terrain alerting function of the EGPWS generates a caution, which leaves the pilot with a response time between 40-60 sec, followed by a warning, which leaves the pilot between 20-30 sec to react.

learning.explanation: The Flight Warning System (FWS) draws the attention of the crew to the existence of an abnormal condition by supplying indications that identify such conditions according to an internal logic system. It also has the abilities to prioritize warnings as follows: Advisory message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action MAY be required. They may be of any color except red and preferably not amber. Caution message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action WILL be required. They are the next highest priority alert messages after warning messages, and they are usually amber. Warning messages are triggered for situations such as the VMO/MMO exceedance or stall warning. key_points: RADIO ALTIMETER (figure 1) The Radio Altimeter is a device capable of measuring the height of an aircraft above ground with a high degree of accuracy
The radio altimeter has two other important functions: - It supplies the automatic flight system with data to affect automatic landings when used in association with the ILS / MLS
- It furnishes height information and rate of change of height to the Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS), and is a crucial component of this system
learning.explanation: RADIO ALTIMETER (figure 1) The Radio Altimeter is a device capable of measuring the height of an aircraft above ground with a high degree of accuracy. The radio altimeter has two other important functions: - It supplies the automatic flight system with data to affect automatic landings when used in association with the ILS / MLS. - It furnishes height information and rate of change of height to the Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS), and is a crucial component of this system. The instrument makes use of primary radio principles transmitting a Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave (FMCW) in an elliptical pattern vertically below the aircraft. GPWS The aim of the system is to give visual and audible warning signals to a pilot when the aircraft’s proximity to the terrain poses a potential threat to its safety. GPWS enhances flight safety and can prevent those accidents which could result from crew errors or distraction, malfunction or misinterpretation of navigational equipment, or inappropriate ATC instructions. The system operates between 50’ and 2450’ Radio Altitude and automatically selects the correct mode of operation. Terrain Awareness System (TAWS) (figure 2) GPWS does not “look ahead” and any Mode 2 warning when flight is towards high ground will be dependent upon the steepness of the terrain. Hence, a sheer cliff ahead will not generate a mode 2 warning and any subsequent warning due to rising ground beyond the cliff will be delayed until the aircraft is over that ground. This limitation has been overcome by Enhanced GPWS with the Terrain Threat Display. This uses essentially an electronic map of the world (giving ground elevation) and information from the aircraft’s navigational system (be that INS/GPS or any combination). learning.explanation: The information provided by ACAS II is intended to assist flight crew in the safe operation of an aeroplane by providing advice on appropriate action to reduce the risk of collision. This is achieved through Resolution Advisories (RAs), which propose manoeuvres, and through Traffic Advisories (TAs), which are intended to prompt visual acquisition and to act as a warning that an RA may follow. TAs indicate the approximate positions of intruding aircraft that may later cause an RA. RAs that propose manoeuvres in the vertical plain are predicted to increase or maintain separation from the threatening aircraft. Traffic Advisory (TA) means a caution to the flight crew that an aircraft has become a potential collision threat. Resolution Advisory (RA) means a warning to the flight crew of an imminent collision threat, combined with commands for the crew to use in avoiding an airborne collision. When an RA is produced, the pilot flying shall immediately take the corrective action indicated by the RA, even if this conflicts with an Air Traffic Control (ATC) instruction, unless doing so would jeopardise the safety of the aeroplane. key_points: On most modern transport aeroplanes the stall-warning device activates via an angle of attack or Alpha sensor

learning.explanation: On most modern transport aeroplanes the stall-warning device activates via an angle of attack or Alpha sensor. One of these sensors is located on either side of the fuselage near the nose, and detects the change/rate of change of angle of attack of the aeroplane as the airspeed varies. Two independent digital computers are normally installed which compute the proper stall warning based on the angle of attack, flap configuration, and thrust. The computers receive inputs from the: - angle of attack sensor (Alpha probe) - flap position transmitter - N1 and N2 indicators - air/ground relay - air data computers - leading edge module. At a pre-set angle of attack, the circuit completes and an eccentric weight motor attached to the base of either or both control columns operates. The motor in turn vibrates the control column, thus imitating the effect of aerodynamic buffet, and alerts the flight crew before a stall develops. This also displays visually on the Primary Flight Display (PFD). In the event the angle of attack becomes frozen at a specific Angle of Attack, an increase in AoA will not be detected by the computer and a stall warning will then not be triggered.

key_points: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft
The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas
The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft
learning.explanation: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft. The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas. The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. Therefore, if other aircraft do not have a serviceable transponder no protection will be provided against them. In the same way, if any of the concerned aircraft does not have the altitude reporting capability from the mode C transponder, the TCAS II will only issue Traffic Advisories (TA). The TCAS computer uses the aircraft’s configuration data (gear/flaps), pressure altitude from the mode C transponder, and the radio altimeter’s height. The TCAS II has inputs from the radio altimeter in order to gradually inhibit the resolution advisories (RAs) when getting closer to the ground such as during the approach phase. The instrument itself can have a specifically dedicated screen situated on the cockpit’s instruments panel or it can be a variometer on a liquid crystal screen displaying the TAs and RAs. The TCAS II can also be integrated into an EFIS screen or be combined with the weather radar. The resolution advisories issued by the TCAS are either preventive or corrective: Preventive – advise the flight crew to monitor the vertical speed. Corrective – the vertical speed must be corrected without delay. The color and symbols code of the TCAS II is the following: Proximate traffic – white or cyan solid lozenge. Traffic advisory – amber solid circle. Resolution advisory – red full square.

The "RETARD" mode indicates that the autothrottle moves thrust levers to the aft stop
RETARD mode is followed by ARM mode which means that no autothrottle mode engaged
learning.explanation: If the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) displays "RETARD" during cruise flight, this would be an abnormal situation as the "RETARD" mode is normally only displayed during the approach and landing phase of flight. The "RETARD" mode indicates that the autothrottle moves thrust levers to the aft stop. RETARD mode is followed by ARM mode which means that no autothrottle mode engaged. The pilot must manually adjust the thrust to maintain the desired speed or altitude. If the radio altimeter were to provide intermittent or unreliable height information, the autothrottle system may become confused or unable to maintain a stable flight profile. In the event of the FMA displaying "RETARD" during cruise flight, the pilot should immediately take action to manually adjust the engine thrust to maintain a safe and stable flight. The pilot should also follow the appropriate procedures to troubleshoot and correct the issue with the autothrottle system or its inputs, which may involve switching to an alternate system or using manual control of the engines for the remainder of the flight.

content.question: An aircraft is at 400 ft AGL on an approach. What can the TCAS generate regarding an 'intruder'?

key_points: The purpose and function of the TCAS is to alert the flight crew to the presence of other aeroplanes in their vicinity, and where possible provide an escape manoeuvre, should a collision risk arise
TCAS relies on other aeroplane transponders to indicate their presence, so aeroplanes not equipped with this system will appear transparent
Traffic Advisories (TAs) exist when an intruder penetrates the outer bubble caution area and is between 45 and 35 seconds from the collision area
learning.explanation: The purpose and function of the TCAS is to alert the flight crew to the presence of other aeroplanes in their vicinity, and where possible provide an escape manoeuvre, should a collision risk arise. TCAS relies on other aeroplane transponders to indicate their presence, so aeroplanes not equipped with this system will appear transparent. Traffic Advisories (TAs) exist when an intruder penetrates the outer bubble caution area and is between 45 and 35 seconds from the collision area. TAs appear as solid amber circles on the TCAS display and are accompanied by the synthetic voice saying “Traffic, Traffic”. This is a potential collision threat. Resolution Advisories (RAs) exist when an intruder penetrates the inner bubble warning area and is between 35 and 15 seconds from the collision area. RAs appear as solid red rectangles on the TCAS display accompanied by various synthetic voice warnings. RAs indicate a serious collision threat. The TCAS also has feeds from the radio altimeter to modify the RAs received when in close proximity to the ground. There are no instructions and aural alert given at all when the aircraft is below 400 ft AGL, no descent RAs are given below 1000 ft AGL and no increase rate of descent commands below 1450 ft AGL.

key_points: EGPWS Functions The aircraft was fitted with an EGPWS which provided basic ground proximity warning functions and enhanced functions

Basic Functions: Mode 1 – Excessive Descent Rate Mode 2 – Excessive Closure to Terrain Mode 3 – Altitude Loss After Takeoff Mode 4 – Unsafe Terrain Clearance Mode 5 – Excessive Deviation Below Glideslope Mode 6 – Advisory Callouts Mode 7 – Windshear Alerting Enhanced Functions: Terrain Clearance Floor Terrain Look-ahead Alerting Windshear Alerts - Terrain Look-Ahead Alerting This is accomplished (when enabled) based on aircraft position, flight path angle, track, and speed relative to the terrain database image forward the aircraft
Through sophisticated look-ahead algorithms, both caution and warning alerts are generated if terrain or an obstacle conflict with “ribbons” projected forward of the aircraft
learning.explanation: EGPWS Functions The aircraft was fitted with an EGPWS which provided basic ground proximity warning functions and enhanced functions. Basic Functions: Mode 1 – Excessive Descent Rate Mode 2 – Excessive Closure to Terrain Mode 3 – Altitude Loss After Takeoff Mode 4 – Unsafe Terrain Clearance Mode 5 – Excessive Deviation Below Glideslope Mode 6 – Advisory Callouts Mode 7 – Windshear Alerting Enhanced Functions: Terrain Clearance Floor Terrain Look-ahead Alerting Windshear Alerts - Terrain Look-Ahead Alerting This is accomplished (when enabled) based on aircraft position, flight path angle, track, and speed relative to the terrain database image forward the aircraft. Through sophisticated look-ahead algorithms, both caution and warning alerts are generated if terrain or an obstacle conflict with “ribbons” projected forward of the aircraft. These ribbons project down, forward, then up from the aircraft with a width starting at 1/4 nm and extending out at ±3° laterally, more if turning. The look-down and up angles are a function of the aircraft flight path angle, and the look-down distance a function of the aircraft’s altitude with respect to the nearest or destination runway. This relationship prevents undesired alerts when taking off or landing. The look-ahead distance is a function of the aircraft’s speed, and distance to the nearest runway. A terrain conflict intruding into the caution ribbon activates EGPWS caution lights and the aural message “CAUTION TERRAIN, CAUTION TERRAIN” or “TERRAIN AHEAD, TERRAIN AHEAD”. An obstacle conflict provides a “CAUTION OBSTACLE, CAUTION OBSTACLE” or “OBSTACLE AHEAD, OBSTACLE AHEAD” message. The caution alert is given typically 60 seconds ahead of the terrain/obstacle conflict and is repeated every seven seconds as long as the conflict remains within the caution area. When the warning ribbon is intruded (typically 30 seconds prior to the terrain/obstacle conflict), EGPWS warning lights activate and the aural message “TERRAIN, TERRAIN, PULL UP” or “OBSTACLE, OBSTACLE, PULL UP” is enunciated with “PULL UP” repeating continuously while the conflict is within the warning area.

key_points: The Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS) was developed in order to reduce the risk of mid-air collisions between aircraft

learning.explanation: The Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System (TCAS) was developed in order to reduce the risk of mid-air collisions between aircraft. It serves as a last-resort safety net irrespective of any separation standards. The Resolution Advisory (RA) will give the most optimum avoidance manoeuvre. RA is issued when the estimated time to the closest point of approach with the conflicting aircraft is 15-34 seconds. Since pilots are expected to react to the RA within 5 seconds, it effectively leaves 10-29 seconds to avoid a possible collision. Therefore, pilots must first initiate the RA manoeuvre and only then worry about making the ATC calls. Following a mid-air collision accident, in which one crew ignored the indication of the system, all European operators must clearly instruct their crews to follow the commands of this system despite possible conflicting ATC instructions. It is recognised that workload is often high during a TCAS RA encounter, nonetheless pilots shall notify ATC as soon as possible using the standard phraseology.

key_points: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic Advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft
The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas
The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft
learning.explanation: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic Advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft. The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas. The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. Therefore, if other aircraft do not have a serviceable transponder no protection will be provided against them. In the same way, if any of the concerned aircraft does not have the altitude reporting capability from the mode C transponder, the TCAS II will only issue Traffic Advisories (TA). The TCAS computer uses aircraft’s configuration data (gear/flaps), pressure altitude from the mode C transponder, and the radio altimeter’s height. The TCAS II has inputs from the radio altimeter in order to gradually inhibit the resolution advisories (RAs) when getting closer to the ground such as during the approach phase. The instrument itself can have a specifically dedicated screen situated on the cockpit’s instruments panel or it can be a variometer on a liquid crystal screen displaying the TAs and RAs. The TCAS II can also be integrated in an EFIS screen or be combined with the weather radar. The Resolution Advisories issued by the TCAS are either preventive or corrective: Preventive – advise the flight crew to monitor the vertical speed. Corrective – the vertical speed must be corrected without delay. The color and symbols code of the TCAS II is the following: Proximate traffic – white or cyan solid lozenge. Traffic Advisory – amber solid circle. Resolution Advisory – red full square.

learning.explanation: The radio altimeter can be defined as a self-contained on-board aid used to measure the true height of the aircraft. The RA operates between 4200 MHz and 4400 MHz and the maximum range for the indication is typically from the ground up to 2500 ft. Therefore, besides the autopilot (for obvious reasons) it is the primary source of information during an automatic landing. The transition from one phase to another during the autoland is based on the height measured by the radio altimeter. For example, at 50 ft AGL the glideslope signal is disconnected, and between 50 ft AGL and touch down, the autopilot will keep a vertical speed depending on the radio altimeter height, as this is more precise than the barometric altitude. learning.explanation: The vertical distance of the lowest structure on the airframe, which is the extended main gear, from the ground surface is measured by a device called a radio altimeter. learning.explanation: To augment pre-stall buffet, light aircraft normally have an audible stall-warning device that operates just before the stall. This device is activated by a moving vane (Flapper Switch), positioned approximately midway along the wing, just below the leading edge as seen in figure 1. Airflow holds down the vane at normal operating angles of attack, but just before the wing stalls, movement of the stagnation point around the leading edge lifts the vane (figure 2). key_points: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft
The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas

learning.explanation: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft. The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas. When a threat is detected, RA instructions will be announced on the appropriate TCAS II display in each of the involved aircraft. The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. Therefore, if other aircraft do not have a serviceable transponder no protection will be provided against them. In the same way, if any of the concerned aircraft does not have the altitude reporting capability from the mode C transponder, the TCAS II will only issue Traffic Advisories (TA). The TCAS computer uses the aircraft’s configuration data (gear/flaps), pressure altitude from the mode C transponder, and the radio altimeter’s height. The TCAS II has inputs from the radio altimeter in order to gradually inhibit the resolution advisories (RAs) when getting closer to the ground such as during the approach phase. The instrument itself can have a specifically dedicated screen situated on the cockpit’s instruments panel or it can be a variometer on a liquid crystal screen displaying the TAs and RAs. The TCAS II can also be integrated into an EFIS screen or be combined with the weather radar. The resolution advisories issued by the TCAS are either preventive or corrective: Preventive – advise the flight crew to monitor the vertical speed. Corrective – the vertical speed must be corrected without delay. The color and symbols code of the TCAS II is the following: Proximate traffic – white or cyan solid lozenge. Traffic advisory – amber solid circle. Resolution advisory – red full square.

key_points: A Radio Altimeter provides a very accurate reference of aircraft height above the ground
It acheives this by transmitting radio waves vertically downwards from an aerial on the underside of the fuselage which are then reflected back from the ground and received via a separate aerial
The height of the aircraft is proprotional to the time taken for the radio waves to be received after being transmitted
learning.explanation: A Radio Altimeter provides a very accurate reference of aircraft height above the ground. It acheives this by transmitting radio waves vertically downwards from an aerial on the underside of the fuselage which are then reflected back from the ground and received via a separate aerial. The height of the aircraft is proprotional to the time taken for the radio waves to be received after being transmitted. In most Commercial Air Transport (CAT) aircraft the radio altimeter is operational up to 2500 ft above ground level (AGL) The radio altitude display will disappear from the PFD when above 2500 ft. As well as displaying height to the pilots the output from the radio altimeter is used by other systems including TCAS, GPWS/TAWS and the Autopilot. Autopilots need very accurate height information to perform an automatic landing as the flare manoeuvre is based on the height of the lowest wheels of the landing gear above the runway. For this reason a radio altimeter has to be calibrated so that it reads 0 ft when, in the landing configuration, the wheels touch the runway. The height between the fuselage aerials and the lowest wheel of the landing gear, in the landing configuration, is known as the Residual Height and will be different for each aircraft type. Note: The ‘landing configuration’ is with the landing gear oleos fully extended and the aircraft in a nose high approach attitude. After landing with the oleos compressed and the fuselage level the residual distance will be less so the radio altimeter may indicate a small minus figure.

learning.explanation: GPWS The aim of the system is to give visual and audible warning signals to a pilot when the aircraft’s proximity to the terrain poses a potential threat to its safety. GPWS enhances flight safety and can prevent those accidents which could result from crew errors or distraction, malfunction or misinterpretation of navigational equipment, or inappropriate ATC instructions. Terrain Awareness System (TAWS) (figure 1) GPWS does not “look ahead” and any Mode 2 warning when flight is towards high ground will be dependent upon the steepness of the terrain. Hence, a sheer cliff ahead will not generate a mode 2 warning and any subsequent warning due to rising ground beyond the cliff will be delayed until the aircraft is over that ground. This limitation has been overcome by Enhanced GPWS with the Terrain Threat Display. This uses essentially an electronic map of the world (giving ground elevation) and information from the aircraft’s navigational system (be that INS/GPS or any combination). Seven main conditions give rise to audible and visual alerts. These conditions are described as MODES: - MODE 1 - Excessive Barometric Descent Rate - MODE 2 - Excessive Terrain Closure Rate - MODE 3 - Altitude Loss after Take-off or Go-around - MODE 4A - Unsafe Terrain Clearance with Landing Gear Not down - MODE 4B - Unsafe Terrain Clearance with Flaps Not in Landing Configuration - MODE 5 - Below Glide Slope Deviation Alert - MODE 6A - Below Selected Minimum Radio Altitude - MODE 6B Altitude Call-outs and Bank Angle Alert - MODE 7 Windshear Alerting

learning.explanation: 022.12.08.01.06: Explain the potential implications of a faulty radio-altimeter and how this in particular may affect the following systems: autothrust (flare/retard); ground-proximity warning systems (GPWSs). The vertical distance of the lowest structure on the airframe, which is the extended main gear, from the ground surface is measured by a device called a radio altimeter. Indications given by this device are therefore equal to the aircraft’s true height. Its indication ranges from 0 to 2500 ft and besides visually providing the actual radio altitude, the system also issues aural alerts when passing certain radio heights. In addition to direct display, the radio altitude information is also sent to other systems, such as: flight director and autopilot systems (including Autoland and auto thrust), the GPWS, as well as the airborne or traffic collision avoidance system (ACAS/TCAS). With regards to this question: The GPWS system is active at all heights at which the low range radio altimeter can function, i.e. between ground and 2500 ft AGL. A dangerous situation that could be caused by a false radio height is a mode change in the automatic thrust control. If a radio altimeter erraneously reports a radio height of 50 ft or below while the autothrust system is engages in approach mode, it will trigger the flare or retard step of the autoland sequence and reduce thrust to zero for the flare.

The system generates a windshear warning whenever the predicted energy level for the aircraft falls below a predetermined threshold. A visual warning message is also displayed on each Electronic Attitude Director Indicator (EADI), and remains there until the windshear condition subsides. The windshear warnings also take priority over all other GPWS modes, and only become active on take-off after rotation.

The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. learning.explanation: The purpose of the stall warning system is to warn the pilot of an impending stall. learning.explanation: The antennas used by TCAS II include a directional antenna that is mounted on the top of the aircraft and either an omnidirectional or a directional antenna mounted on the bottom of the aircraft. Most installations use the optional directional antenna on the bottom of the aircraft. These antennas transmit interrogations on 1030 MHz at varying power levels in each of four 90˚ azimuth segments. The bottom mounted antenna transmits fewer interrogations and at a lower power than the top-mounted antenna. These antennas also receive transponder replies, at 1090 MHz, and send these replies to the TCAS Processor. The directional antennas permit the partitioning of replies to reduce synchronous garbling.

TCAS, which is an abbreviation for Traffic Alert and Collision Avoidance System, is the current equipment used to achieve this function, and provides traffic information within approximately 30 miles of the aeroplane. The purpose and function of the TCAS is to alert the flight crew to the presence of other aeroplanes in their vicinity, and where possible provide an escape manoeuvre, should a collision risk arise. TCAS II detects intruders in the TCAS aircraft’s vicinity, assesses the collision risk and presents warnings to the crew in the form of TAs and Resolution Advisories (RAs). RAs offer manoeuvring advice in the vertical plane to resolve conflict. INFORMATION DISPLAY The action required to comply with the Resolution Advisory displays on a specialised Resolution Advisory/Vertical Speed Indicator (RA /VSI) instrument using a colour liquid crystal screen, which shows the rate of climb, and intruder information. On other aeroplanes, the intruder information displays on the EFIS Navigation Display screen. In either case, the symbology used is the same: Hollow White or blue diamond - Other traffic not offering a threat. Solid White of blue diamond - Traffic within 6 nm and 1200 ft vertically. Solid Yellow Circle - Traffic advisory. Solid Red Square - Resolution advisory. Each symbol has a data tag attached to it, which appears in the same colour as the associated symbols. This data provides the altitude of the target in reference to your own aeroplane’s altitude (e.g. + 06 indicates 600 ft above). An arrow also indicates whether the ‘target’ is climbing or descending. There is also often provision to display momentarily absolute pressure altitude in hundreds of feet of pressure altitude. Where the target is a mode A transponder with no height transmissions, no data tag appears and no RA is given. If the target does not have a functioning transponder, the TCAS system is unable to detect its presence.

key_points: The Flight Warning System (FWS) draws the attention of the crew to the existence of an abnormal condition by supplying indications that identify such conditions according to an internal logic system
It also has the abilities to prioritize warnings as follows: Advisory message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action MAY be required
They may be of any colour except red and preferably not amber
learning.explanation: The Flight Warning System (FWS) draws the attention of the crew to the existence of an abnormal condition by supplying indications that identify such conditions according to an internal logic system. It also has the abilities to prioritize warnings as follows: Advisory message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action MAY be required. They may be of any colour except red and preferably not amber. Caution message – crew awareness IS required, and subsequent crew action WILL be required. They are the next highest priority alert messages after warning messages, and they are usually amber. Warning message – immediate recognition and corrective or compensatory action by the crew IS required. They are the highest priority alert messages and always of red colour on the displays. Warning messages are triggered for situations such as the VMO/MMO exceedance or stall warning. Aural alerts are used to attract attention via a different sensory input. All warnings and most cautions are provided with aural alerts (fire bell, autopilot/autothrottle disconnect wail, stall warner, GPWS, etc.). They serve a different purpose to visual indications, and can be used alongside for increased attention. Haptic and tactile alerts (such as the stick shaker) can also be used to alert the pilot further, and can allow the pilot to make sense of the inputs faster and perform associated procedures better. Note: The only possible answer here includes aural alerts, but for a caution, this is not always strictly the case, such as the B737 master caution (which has no aural alert), but the question is arguably still correct, as this light indication alone might not cause the pilot to look up at all from their paperwork (the master caution light is difficult to miss with normal head positioning whilst looking forwards.). This is still the most correct answer by far over the other options.

content.question: In case of radio altimeter failure, the following system(s) is/are affected…
