learning.explanation: 022.12.08.01.06: Explain the potential implications of a faulty radio-altimeter and how this in particular may affect the following systems: autothrust (flare/retard); ground-proximity warning systems (GPWSs). The vertical distance of the lowest structure on the airframe, which is the extended main gear, from the ground surface is measured by a device called a radio altimeter. Indications given by this device are therefore equal to the aircraft’s true height. Its indication ranges from 0 to 2500 ft and besides visually providing the actual radio altitude, the system also issues aural alerts when passing certain radio heights. In addition to direct display, the radio altitude information is also sent to other systems, such as: flight director and autopilot systems (including Autoland and auto thrust), the GPWS, as well as the airborne or traffic collision avoidance system (ACAS/TCAS). With regards to this question: The GPWS system is active at all heights at which the low range radio altimeter can function, i.e. between ground and 2500 ft AGL. A dangerous situation that could be caused by a false radio height is a mode change in the automatic thrust control. If a radio altimeter erraneously reports a radio height of 50 ft or below while the autothrust system is engages in approach mode, it will trigger the flare or retard step of the autoland sequence and reduce thrust to zero for the flare. We believe that the option "TCAS" should not be within the available options as an isolated item - it should be included in the correct option as it is also affected by a radio altimeter malfunction/failure.

options.B: To coordinate TAs between aircraft.
options.C: To gradually enhance an RA when the aircraft nears the ground.
options.D: To gradually inhibit an RA when the aircraft nears the ground.

key_points: TCAS alerts the crew to possible conflicting traffic
It interrogates operating transponders in other airplanes, tracks the other airplanes by analyzing the transponder replies, and predicts the flight paths and positions
This system provides advisory and traffic displays of the other airplanes to the flight crew
learning.explanation: TCAS alerts the crew to possible conflicting traffic. It interrogates operating transponders in other airplanes, tracks the other airplanes by analyzing the transponder replies, and predicts the flight paths and positions. This system provides advisory and traffic displays of the other airplanes to the flight crew. Neither advisory, guidance, nor traffic display is provided for other airplanes which do not have operating transponders. TCAS equipment interrogates the transponders of other airplanes to determine their range, bearing, and altitude. A traffic advisory (TA) is generated when the other airplane is approximately 40 seconds from the point of closest approach. If the other airplane continues to close, a resolution advisory (RA) is generated when the other airplane is approximately 25 seconds from the point of closest approach. The RA provides aural warning and guidance as well as maneuver guidance to maintain or increase separation from the traffic. If altitude data from the traffic aircraft’s transponder is not available, no RA can be provided. The TCAS also has feeds from the radio altimeter to modify the RAs received when in close proximity to the ground. There are no instructions given at all when the aircraft is below 400 ft AGL, no descent RAs are given below 1000 ft AGL and no increase rate of descent commands below 1450 ft AGL. Below 1,000 feet when the TA/RA mode is selected on the transponder panel, TA only mode is enabled automatically and the TCAS message TA ONLY displays on the ND. The system will also take aircraft configuration/performance into consideration when deciding an avoiding action. When the aircraft has gear and/or flap deployed its climb performance will be poor so TCAS will avoid giving climbing demands for an RA.

content.question: A TCAS II provides…

options.B: the intruder relative position and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance manoeuvre within the horizontal plane only.
options.C: the intruder relative position and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance manoeuvre within the vertical plane only.
options.D: a simple intruder proximity warning.

key_points: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft
The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas
The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft
learning.explanation: A TCAS II provides the intruder relative position (Traffic advisory and proximate traffic) and possibly an indication of a collision avoidance maneuver (Resolution Advisory) within the vertical plane only, by comparing the mode C pressure altitudes of the aircraft. The instrument determines the bearing of an intruder by using two specific antennas. The TCAS II can only operate normally with a fully operational transponder since it is using the replies from the transponders of other aircraft. Therefore, if other aircraft do not have a serviceable transponder no protection will be provided against them. In the same way, if any of the concerned aircraft does not have the altitude reporting capability from the mode C transponder, the TCAS II will only issue Traffic Advisories (TA). The TCAS computer uses the aircraft’s configuration data (gear/flaps), pressure altitude from the mode C transponder, and the radio altimeter’s height. The TCAS II has inputs from the radio altimeter in order to gradually inhibit the resolution advisories (RAs) when getting closer to the ground such as during the approach phase. The instrument itself can have a specifically dedicated screen situated on the cockpit’s instruments panel or it can be a variometer on a liquid crystal screen displaying the TAs and RAs. The TCAS II can also be integrated into an EFIS screen or be combined with the weather radar. The resolution advisories issued by the TCAS are either preventive or corrective: Preventive – advise the flight crew to monitor the vertical speed. Corrective – the vertical speed must be corrected without delay. The color and symbols code of the TCAS II is the following: Proximate traffic – white or cyan solid lozenge. Traffic advisory – amber solid circle. Resolution advisory – red full square.

learning.explanation: EASA learning objective 022.12.10.01.14 states: Explain that in high-density traffic areas the range may automatically be decreased in order to enable detection of the threats in the proximity of the aircraft due to a limitation of the maximum number of possible intruders the system is able to process. and learning objective 022.12.10.01.13 states: Explain the principle of ‘reduced surveillance’. TCAS II uses a Mode S transponder, the same transponder that's interrogated by air traffic control (ATC) to provide the aircrafts altitude, identity and other flight information. The normal operational range of TCAS II is 14 nm and it can detect up to 30 aircraft. In high density traffic areas the ATC transponder functions need to be protected. This is achieved by limiting the amount of time the transponder spends on TCAS functions to approximately 2%. When multiple intruder aircraft are detected TCAS II enters a 'reduced surveillance' mode by extending the interrogation rate from 1 second to 5 seconds and reducing the range to 5nm to prioritise the nearest threats.

Seven main conditions give rise to audible and visual alerts. These conditions are described as MODES. MODE 7 This mode provides both aural and visual warnings if a windshear condition exists during the take-off and approach phases of flight, below 1500 ft radio altitude. The aural warning consists of a two-tone siren, which is followed by an aural warning of “WINDSHEAR, WINDSHEAR, WINDSHEAR”. A visual warning message is also displayed on each Electronic Attitude Director Indicator (EADI), and remains there until the windshear condition subsides. The windshear warnings also take priority over all other GPWS modes, and only become active on take-off after rotation.

learning.explanation: Note: We have had lots of feedback on Question 222062 about a very similar question with EGPWS. The feedback is therefore very strong for this question. However, if you see a question about GPWS (not the enhanced EGPWS), remember that it does not have a terrain database so cannot show terrain on the ND. If you do see a question about only GPWS, please go to question 222062 and let us know in the comments, we want to check if it is being asked alongside this one, thanks! GPWS The aim of the GPWS (Ground Proximity Warning System) is to give visual and audible warning signals to a pilot when the aircraft’s proximity to the terrain poses a potential threat to its safety. GPWS enhances flight safety and can prevent those accidents which could result from crew errors or distraction, malfunction or misinterpretation of navigational equipment, or inappropriate ATC instructions. The system operates between 50’ and 2450’ Radio Altitude and automatically selects the correct mode of operation, using the radio altimeter and other inputs to automatically select the correct mode of operation, delivering one of many different aural alerts (made up of aural cautions [yellow], and aural warnings [red], depending on the mode and distance from terrain/impact) to the flight crew, such as "SINK RATE" when the rate of descent is too high, or "GLIDESLOPE", when the aircraft deviates too far below the glideslope. EGPWS is called enhanced GPWS, and is the much more modern version of the older GPWS system. It uses a terrain database to "look ahead" at the aircraft's flight path and call out if it is on track to hit terrain. This is something that the older GPWS system could only guess at, as it could only measure the distance from terrain directly below the aircraft. This means that as well as the standard GPWS alerts and warnings, EGPWS can give the pilots a view of the nearby terrain on their navigation display (ND) to aid situational awareness and their subsequent terrain escape manoeuvre.

key_points: The Alert Messages system continuously monitors a large number of inputs from engine and airframe systems sensors and will detect any malfunctioning of systems

learning.explanation: The Alert Messages system continuously monitors a large number of inputs from engine and airframe systems sensors and will detect any malfunctioning of systems. If this should occur, then appropriate messages are generated and displayed on the upper display unit in a sequence corresponding to the level of urgency of action to be taken. Level A - Warning requiring immediate corrective action. They are displayed in red. Master warning lights are also illuminated, and aural warnings (e.g. fire bell) from a central warning system are given. Level B - Cautions require immediate crew awareness and future crew action. They are displayed in amber, and also by message caution lights. An aural tone is also repeated twice. Level C - Advisories requiring crew awareness. Also displayed in amber. No caution lights or aural tones are associated with this level. From the options given, only an engine failure would require immediate crew action/awareness, thus the rest of the messages could be displayed as an advisory.

content.question: Choose the option which correctly describes the difference between TAWS, HTAWS and GPWS…

options.A: TAWS, HTAWS and GPWS are the same system but the names are different depending on the manufacturer.
options.B: TAWS and HTAWS use a pressure altimeter and a 2D database and GPWS uses a radio altimeter.
options.C: TAWS and HTAWS use a radar altimeter and a 3D database and GPWS uses a radio altimeter.
options.D: One is for aeroplanes and the other one is for helicopters.

key_points: The first generation of GPWS consist of little more than a radio altimeter
In such a system, the radio obtains an accurate vertical measurement of the distance from the aircraft to the Earth’s surface immediately below it
The GPWS does not “look ahead” and any Mode 2 warning when flight is towards high ground will be dependent upon the steepness of the terrain
learning.explanation: The first generation of GPWS consist of little more than a radio altimeter. In such a system, the radio obtains an accurate vertical measurement of the distance from the aircraft to the Earth’s surface immediately below it. The GPWS does not “look ahead” and any Mode 2 warning when flight is towards high ground will be dependent upon the steepness of the terrain. However, this limitation has been overcome by Enhanced GPWS with the Terrain Threat Display. This uses essentially an electronic map of the world (giving ground elevation) and information from the aircraft’s navigational system (be that INS/GPS or any combination). Given the location of the aircraft, its course and height (either from the ADC or derived from GPS) a display can be created showing the locations of terrain that could threaten the safety of the aircraft. Note: It is important to note that the EGPWS has the basic functions of the GPWS to which the 'look ahead' function is added. This means that the EGPWS also relies on the Radio Altimeter as one of its inputs. GPWS = Ground Proximity Warning System TAWS = Terrain Awareness Warning System HTAWS = Helicopter Terrain Awareness Warning System

Which of the following statements about stall warning systems are true?
1. The flap/slat setting, calibrated airspeed, and thrust are required inputs for systems using an Angle of Attack sensor
2. Microswitches in light aircraft are activated by a plate or vane in the airflow close to the leading edge of the wing

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.
options.D: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: The first statement refers to Stall Warning inputs
On Stall Warning systems, two independent digital computers are normally installed which compute the proper stall warning based on the angle of attack, flap configuration, and thrust

The computers receive inputs from: - the angle of attack sensor (Alpha probe) - the flap position transmitter - the N1 and N2 indicators - the air/ground relay - the air data computers (CAS) - the leading edge module
learning.explanation: The first statement refers to Stall Warning inputs. On Stall Warning systems, two independent digital computers are normally installed which compute the proper stall warning based on the angle of attack, flap configuration, and thrust. The computers receive inputs from: - the angle of attack sensor (Alpha probe) - the flap position transmitter - the N1 and N2 indicators - the air/ground relay - the air data computers (CAS) - the leading edge module. The second statement refers to the Stall Warning device usually found on small aircraft. Light aircraft normally have an audible stall-warning device that operates just before the stall. This device is activated by a moving vane (Flapper Switch), positioned approximately midway along the wing, just below the leading edge as seen in figure 2. Airflow holds down the vane at normal operating angles of attack, but just before the wing stalls, movement of the stagnation point around the leading edge lifts the vane (figure 3). This closes a micro-switch and sounds a buzzer in the cockpit, giving warning of an impending stall.

It must provide a distinctive aural warning and visible signal to the flight crew in case of: Mode Meaning Initial Aural Alert Second Aural Warning Mode 1 Excessive descent rate “SINK RATE, SINK RATE” “WHOOP WHOOP PULL UP” (twice) Mode 2 Excessive terrain closure rate (=dangerous ground proximity) “TERRAIN TERRAIN” “WHOOP WHOOP PULL UP” (continuously until the radio altitude stopped reducing and an increase of 300’ baro is measured) Mode 3 Altitude loss after take-off or go-around "DON`T SINK" (twice) NONE Mode 4 Unsafe terrain clearance with flaps and landing gear NOT in landing configuration “TOO LOW GEAR,” “TOO LOW FLAPS,” “TOO LOW TERRAIN” NONE Mode 5 Downward glideslope deviation “GLIDESLOPE, GLIDESLOPE” at half volume “GLIDESLOPE, GLIDESLOPE” at full volume Mode 6a (not required by OPS-1) When passing the decision height “MINIMUMS, MINIMUMS” NONE Mode 6b (not required by OPS-1) Excessive bank angle “BANK ANGLE, BANK ANGLE” NONE Mode 7 (not required by OPS-1) When expecting or already encountering wind shear “CAUTION WINDSHEAR” “WINDSHEAR, WIDSHEAR”

The different display modes of the ND are the following: EXPANDED, MAP or ARC mode: an expanded view of the compass rose, with the current heading at the top (“heading-up orientation”) VOR, FULL VOR or ROSE VOR mode: the entire compass rose in a heading-up orientation APP or ROSE ILS mode: the entire compass rose in heading-up orientation, with only the ILS localiser visible, an additional glide slope indication appears to the right PLAN mode: the upcoming flight plan waypoints are depicted in a “north-up” orientation, the display range can be adjusted

Some questions will ask you to determine the mode selected on a given ND. To do so you need to ask yourself two questions: Is it a Full-Rose (360° compass rose displayed) or an Expanded Mode (90° of the compass rose displayed with ±45° either side of the centerline)? content.question:
During take-off, the aircraft flies through a flock of birds. The ECAM announces an engine failure. Some of the items on the on-screen checklist contain a "confirm" step. For instance:
PM: "Engine failure engine number 1... confirm"
PF: "CONFIRM"
Why do pilots need to confirm?

options.A: To prevent inappropriate reactions caused by a misinterpretation of the malfunction by the system.
options.B: To synchronize the information and confirm the engine failure with the air traffic control for coordination purposes.
options.C: To satisfy a bureaucratic requirement for pilots to verbally acknowledge the failure, regardless of its obvious nature.
options.D: To fulfill regulatory requirements and maintain proper documentation for incident reporting.

learning.explanation: 022.13.04.01.09: Describe an appropriate procedure for following an on - screen checklist associated with a failure scenario including the following confirm the failure with the other flight crew member prior to performing any of the actions; seek confirmation prior to manipulating any guarded switches or thrust levers; follow the checklist slowly and methodically assess the possible implications of making certain selections, such as opening the fuel cross-feed if there is a fuel leak even though the electronic checklist may ask for the action. IMPORTANT NOTE: Please note that this question was generated based on limited feedback, and we have incomplete information about the available options. We have included this question in our database in the hopes that someone might recognize it and provide additional details. Your assistance is greatly appreciated. Thank you! Pilots should use caution and critical thinking when relying on an on-screen checklist for dealing with malfunctions. Although the checklist provides valuable guidance, pilots should remember that the actions displayed were programmed in advance and may not fully adapt to the specific situation. Computers can only monitor predefined parameters and trigger programmed responses, whereas human pilots can use knowledge-based behavior to respond dynamically. To ensure the effective use of automated on-screen checklists while mitigating their limitations, it is recommended to follow a specific procedure. Firstly, it is crucial to verify the reported failure by consulting another member of the flight crew and assessing both supporting and contradictory data. This step is essential to prevent inappropriate reactions caused by a misinterpretation of the malfunction by the system. Once the reported malfunction has been confirmed, the on-screen checklist should be followed meticulously and deliberately. Each selection should be made with careful consideration of its implications. When dealing with highly critical actions like operating thrust levers or guarded switches, extra caution must be exercised, and explicit confirmation from the other crew member should always be sought. "CONFIRM" Step The word "confirm" is added to the checklist items when both flight crew members must verbally agree before action is taken. During an inflight non-normal situation, verbal confirmation is required for: An engine thrust lever And engine start lever An engine, APU or cargo fire switch A generator drive disconnect switch An IRS mode selector, when only one IRS is failed A flight control switch

content.question: On the Primary Flight Display (PFD) of a Boeing 737, how is the pressure fed to the altimeter, and how is it connected?

options.A: Static pressure, with a line from the static port directly connected to the instrument
options.B: Static pressure, by transducer to the Air Data Computer (ADC) and then to the instrument
options.C: Total pressure, with a direct line to the static port
options.D: Dynamic pressure, with a line from the pitot tube

key_points: A PFD is an electronic display screen which replaces the conventional primary flight instruments
Although a PFD displays altitude, the actual calculation of altitude and other air data is carried out by an Air Data Computer (ADC)
Altitude calculation is based on the measurement of atmospheric static pressure which reduces with altitude
learning.explanation: A PFD is an electronic display screen which replaces the conventional primary flight instruments. Although a PFD displays altitude, the actual calculation of altitude and other air data is carried out by an Air Data Computer (ADC). Altitude calculation is based on the measurement of atmospheric static pressure which reduces with altitude. In a conventional mechanical altimeter static pressure is fed to the instrument via a line from the static port. An aneroid capsule inside the instrument, connected to the display pointers, expands and contracts with changes in static pressure. An Air Data Computer needs a static pressure input to be able to calculate altitude but this needs to be a digital input. Thius is acheived by using an Air Data Module (ADM) which contains solid state pressure tranducers which convert the pressure from the static port into a digital signal that the ADC can use. The ADC then feeds that information to the PFD and any other systems that require it.

Additionally, COMMISSION REGULATION (EC) No 859/2008 states, for IFR or night operations — Flight and navigational instruments and associated equipment (OPS 1.652) (l) Those aeroplanes with a maximum certificated take-off mass in excess of 5700 kg or having a maximum approved passenger seating configuration of more than nine seats must be equipped with an additional, standby, attitude indi- cator (artificial horizon), capable of being used from either pilot’s station, that: 1. is powered continuously during normal operation and, after a total failure of the normal electrical generating system is powered from a source independent of the normal electrical generating system; 2. provides reliable operation for a minimum of 30 minutes after total failure of the normal electrical generating system, taking into account other loads on the emergency power supply and operational procedures; 3. operates independently of any other attitude indicating system; 4. is operative automatically after total failure of the normal electrical generating system; and 5. is appropriately illuminated during all phases of operation, except for aeroplanes with a maximum certificated take-off mass of 5700 kg or less, already registered in a Member State on 1 April 1995, equipped with a standby attitude indicator in the left-hand instrument panel.

A HUD is a class of collimated display. The components of a typical HUD installation include: HUD projector and stowable combiner; HUD controls such as declutter and dimmer; HUD computer.

key_points: With the EVS, the flight crew are given an enhanced visual perspective of their flight environment
The EVS includes external sensors like infrared cameras to generate real-time images on the PFD or on the HUD
The limitation of the EVS is that infrared cameras use temperature and temperature differences to produce images
learning.explanation: With the EVS, the flight crew are given an enhanced visual perspective of their flight environment. The EVS includes external sensors like infrared cameras to generate real-time images on the PFD or on the HUD. The limitation of the EVS is that infrared cameras use temperature and temperature differences to produce images. This means that high outside temperatures with a large difference in the temperatures of outside objects will produce images of high resolution. Lower outside temperatures with little variation between the temperatures of outside objects will produce images of a poorer resolution. The EVS allows for low visibility operations such as take-offs and landings to be conducted with lower minimum visual requirements. This is because the increased resolution of real-time images enhance the visibility of experienced pilots. Note: This is fundamentally quite different from a SVS (Synthetic Vision System), as asked in a very similar looking question, No. 224897. These questions look similar but are actually the exact opposite answers due to the different systems.

key_points: The Inertial Reference Unit is the strapped down platform that enables navigation through the rate sensors (ring laser gyros) and microprocessors
It consists of three RLGs that measure angular rates and three internal accelerometers measuring acceleration on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal)
The IRS is of the strap down principle – they are attached to the aircraft fuselage, so the acceleration measurements are coordinated with the aircraft’s body axes (pitch, roll, yaw)
learning.explanation: The Inertial Reference Unit is the strapped down platform that enables navigation through the rate sensors (ring laser gyros) and microprocessors. It consists of three RLGs that measure angular rates and three internal accelerometers measuring acceleration on all three aircraft’s body axes (longitudinal, lateral, and normal). The IRS is of the strap down principle – they are attached to the aircraft fuselage, so the acceleration measurements are coordinated with the aircraft’s body axes (pitch, roll, yaw). The aircraft sideslips whenever the nose of the airplane is pointing in the opposite direction that the airplane is banking which will be sensed by the IRS and displayed on the PFD so that the pilot can take appropriate corrective actions.

content.question: During flight, a 'fuel lateral imbalance' caution is displayed and the pilots notice that the left wing tank contents are 2000 kg wheras the right wing contents are 3500 kg. The electronic checklist for dealing with a fuel imbalance is automatically displayed. The pilots are working through the checklist and have reached the item FUEL X FEED - ON, which will pump fuel from one wing to the other. Which option is correct about actioning this item?

options.A: This item should be followed when prompted by the electronic checklist since the computer monitors all the required parameters to ensure its use is safe and appropriate.
options.B: The pilots must use this item if the fuel low level caution changes to a master warning, but if there is NO warning then the pilots can decide if using this item is appropriate.
options.C: The pilots must skip this item and go directly to the part of the checklist that deals with the fuel tank pumps.
options.D: The pilots should be very careful since there is a significant risk of pumping fuel overboard if the fuel imbalance is caused by a fuel leak.

key_points: This question draws its inspiration from EASA learning objective 022
learning.explanation: This question draws its inspiration from EASA learning objective 022.13.04.01.09 which states: Describe an appropriate procedure for following an on-screen checklist associated with a failure scenario including the following: confirm the failure with the other flight crew member prior to performing any of the actions; seek confirmation prior to manipulating any guarded switches or thrust levers; follow the checklist slowly and methodically; assess the possible implications of making certain selections, such as opening the fuel cross-feed if there is a fuel leak even though the electronic checklist may ask for the action. An electronic centralised aircraft monitoring system (ECAM) can only react to triggers from aircraft sensors when deciding which checklist to display to the pilots. In this case the system detects a fuel ‘out of balance’ condition so displays the appropriate checklist which will include actions to try to correct the imbalance. Whenever there is an unexpected fuel quantity indication pilots must always consider the possibility of a fuel leak. Selecting 'FUEL X FEED - ON' when there is a fuel leak could result in pumping the remaining fuel overboard through the leak! There is no caution or warning for a fuel leak, pilots must check the total fuel used against the fuel remaining to ascertain whether there is a leak before deciding to open the fuel x -feed.

Each system in turn is comprised of: - Electronic Attitude Director Indicator (EADI) or Primary Flight Display (PFD) - Electronic Horizontal Situation Indicator (EHSI) or Navigation Display (ND) - Control Panel - Symbol Generator (SG) - Remote Light Sensor Unit Primary Flight Display (PFD) The PFD is part of an Electronic Flight Instrument System (EFIS) display and brings all of the information required to fly the aircraft onto one display

learning.explanation: The Electronic Flight Instrument System presents attitude and navigation information to the pilot on electronic display units in a format that is easier to read and less likely to be misinterpreted than some older mechanical instruments. Each system in turn is comprised of: - Electronic Attitude Director Indicator (EADI) or Primary Flight Display (PFD) - Electronic Horizontal Situation Indicator (EHSI) or Navigation Display (ND) - Control Panel - Symbol Generator (SG) - Remote Light Sensor Unit Primary Flight Display (PFD) The PFD is part of an Electronic Flight Instrument System (EFIS) display and brings all of the information required to fly the aircraft onto one display. It has an EADI normally surrounded by speed, altitude and vertical speed tapes and often a compass display incorporating some minimal navigation information. It also has an area which is used for annunciating flight director, autopilot and autothrust modes and status, known as the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA). Navigation Display (ND) A variety of distinct instruments featured on a traditional airplane instrument panel are replaced by the Electronic Horizontal Situation Indicator (EHSI), often known as the Navigation Display (ND). It can be used to display part or all of the information below: - heading flown; - heading or track selected; - bearing to or from a navigation beacon (VHF Omnidirectional Radio Range (VOR), Distance Measuring Equipment (DME)); - lateral deviation from a selected track; - ground speed, distance and time to go; - aeronautical map; - weather information;

It is therefore used for pilot awareness only, and provides no extra information that cannot already be found in the flight deck, but it does reduce workload and increase capacity for more critical stages of flight, where visual reference to the outside world is important, but the pilots also need information from their instruments. When combined with synthetic vision, for example, it can be very useful for showing the pilots the location of the runway, even when they are flying IMC. key_points: Most EFIS Navigation Display systems contain a few different modes
These can each exist in two forms (except for the plan mode), Full Rose and Expanded
Full Rose displays show a full HSI on screen so data can be presented in all directions from the aircraft, such as bearing pointers and CDIs for VORs and ILSs, etc
learning.explanation: Most EFIS Navigation Display systems contain a few different modes. These can each exist in two forms (except for the plan mode), Full Rose and Expanded. Full Rose displays show a full HSI on screen so data can be presented in all directions from the aircraft, such as bearing pointers and CDIs for VORs and ILSs, etc. Expanded displays show just the area ahead of the aircraft (and about 45° either side of the heading) with often less clutter and a more useful view of forward waypoints, etc, useful in the cruise. The 3 modes which have both functions are MAP (showing the planned route ahead, waypoints, beacons, etc.), VOR (giving standard VOR HSI information) and APP (which gives a wider view of the localiser and glide path pointers). On some systems, the VOR/APP (VOR/ILS) mode is combined, and the difference is decided on what frequency is selected, whether that is an ILS or VOR frequency The "PLAN" mode is the odd one out, and shows a North Up view of the planned route. Figure 1 shows a Full Rose VOR display, as is has a HSI showing with VOR in the bottom left, and no vertical information. Figure 2 is a PLAN mode display, showing a North Up view of the route. Figure 3 is an Expanded MAP mode display, as the route ahead is shown, with LNAV and VNAV indicators showing. Figure 4 is an Expanded VOR display, as there is a "VOR" in the bottom left, and there is no glide path indicator on the right. Figure 5 shows an expanded approach (APP) mode display, as there is an "ILS" in the bottom left corner, and both the localiser and glide path indicators are showing, with not much else on the main display. Figure 6 is a Full Rose APP mode display, as it also shows "ILS" in the bottom left and a glide path indicator on the right hand side.

learning.explanation: The purpose of an EFIS system is typically to depict electronically the ADI and HSI information. The system has been optimized to offer even more information which is way more convenient to interpret and use than the conventional dials. It usually consists of several display units such as the Primary Flight Display (PFD), the Navigation Display (ND), the Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) or ECAM. content.question: During take-off a cowling detaches from one of the aircraft engines. This causes damage to some of the engine control circuits, leading to an engine shutdown. The aircraft has an electronic checklist system which takes the pilots through the appropriate actions to deal with engine failure. The last item on the list directs the pilots to attempt an engine relight procedure. Is this appropriate for this particular situation?

options.A: Yes, because the checklist system uses the N1 and N2 indications to assess if a relight is possible, and gives appropriate directions.
options.B: Yes, because the checklist system assesses multiple parameters and presents appropriate actions to the pilots at all times.
options.C: No, because the engine is damaged but the checklist system is NOT able to analyse the extent of this damage.
options.D: No, this is an indication that the checklist system has failed, presenting the pilots with incorrect information and it must NOT be used further.

key_points: EASA learning objective 022
learning.explanation: EASA learning objective 022.13.04.01.08 states: Explain the limited ability of the computer to assess a situation other than using the exceedance of certain thresholds to trigger the main and subsequent events and programmed actions. EASA learning objective 022.13.04.01.07 states: Explain why awareness of the consequences of the actions commanded by the automatic checklist is required. An electronic centralised aircraft monitoring system (ECAM) can only react to triggers from aircraft sensors to decide which checklist to display to the pilots. In this case the system detects the engine failure but is not necessarily aware of physical damage to control circuits. In the absence of a fire warning or vibration the checklist may well suggest an engine relight attempt. Hopefully the pilots will have been alerted by passengers and cabin crew to the loss of the engine cowling so will be considering the possiblity of engine damage. Armed with this information it would be unwise of the pilots to attempt a relight when the extent of the engine damage is unknown.

content.question: Which of the following options is correct regarding the Synthetic Vision System (SVS)?

options.A: The SVS uses data from a dynamic database fed by external sensors during flight to create a synthetic vision representation in a low visibility environment.
options.B: The SVS solely uses data from a predefined fixed database to create a synthetic vision representation of the surroundings of the aircraft.
options.C: The SVS combines the actual sensor information with stored data from a database to create an actual synthetic vision representation of the surroundings of the aircraft.
options.D: The SVS digitally improves the actual sensor data to provide an actual synthetic vision representation of the surroundings of the aircraft in a low visibility environment.

learning.explanation: 022.13.07.01.05: Describe the principle of SVS: an enhanced database used as reference to provide terrain and ground features to be shown on the PFD; limitations due to being a synthetic image not based on actual sensory information thus not lowering landing minima; implications if aircraft position accuracy becomes reduced. Synthetic vision systems (SVS) project an animated image of the terrain and ground features on the background of the primary flight display. This enhances the perception of attitude from the usual blue and brown air/ground symbology to an illustrative image of the surrounding terrain, obstacles, water and land, thus creating a seemingly realistic view of the aircraft’s position even in IMC. SVS constructs a representation of the external environment by merging an improved digital terrain database with an obstruction overlay database. It generates a synthetic view solely relying on this dataset, devoid of any real sensor input or external data input.

learning.explanation: An electronic flight instrument system (EFIS) is a flight deck instrument display system in which the display technology used is electronic rather than electromechanical. Although cathode ray tube (CRT) displays were used at first, liquid crystal displays (LCD) are now more common due to their relatively little power needed for operation. Cathode Ray Tubes (CRT) are known to be too bulky and impractical to fit. During their operation, compared to LCD, CRT displays require more power and generate a lot of heat that needs to be dissipated by active cooling systems. LCD displays have a much lower current consumption (60W for an A320), have no screen burn, have a larger view area, and do not produce radiation, and are much lighter by at least half the mass of a CTR screen.

The HUD replicates the information on the primary flight display (PFD) by showing the following data: - Altitude is displayed on an altitude tape at the right-hand side of the screen. - Airspeed, including a speed trend vector, is displayed on the left-hand side of the screen. - Heading is displayed on the compass rose at the bottom of the screen. - A flight path vector to display the track and vertical flight path of the aircraft is positioned in the centre of the screen along with the pitch attitude of the aircraft. - The flight mode annunciator (FMA) is displayed at the top of the screen so that pilots can be situationally aware of the auto-flight status and auto-flight modes that the aircraft is operating in. - TCAS, TAWS, and wind shear command annunciations will also be displayed when appropriate. They will be displayed in the same positions as with the PFD.

content.question:
Refer to Figure.
The annex shows a modern EFIS instrument layout. The aircraft has two multifunction displays and an electronic standby instrument display. What is the purpose of this standby instrument display and why is it important to have standby instruments in aircraft fitted with EFIS?

options.A: EFIS screens are more susceptible to parallax error when they are read from an angle and the electronic standby instruments are used for clarification.
options.B: The electronic standby indications may be difficult to read but are essential since the failure of an EFIS display means a significant loss of flight data.
options.C: The electronic standby instruments are easy to read and offer a clear presentation of the primary flight parameters when the EFIS becomes too cluttered.
options.D: EFIS is using processed data and the electronic standby instruments use independent sources in order to verify that the processed data is sensible.

key_points: Easa learning objective 022
learning.explanation: Easa learning objective 022.13.03.01.03 states: Explain the need for standby instruments to supplement the EFIS in the event of all the display units failing and the challenge of using these standby instruments, namely their size and position on the flight deck. Easa learning objective 022.13.03.01.02 states: Describe the typical layout of the EFIS display units and how there may be a facility to transfer the information from one display unit on to another if a display unit fails. Aircraft with electronic flight instrument systems (EFIS) must have an independent means of providing vital flight information to the pilots in the event of the failure of the EFIS displays OR their sources of information. EFIS installations are fed with data from an air data computer and inertial reference unit, this data is processed before being displayed on the multifunction displays. The electronic standby instrument display is fed from micro-electromechanical (MEMS) air data sensors connected to independent standby pitot and data sources. Attitude and heading information is provided by a MEMS gyro and the system is fed from a separate power source. Armed with this information it's tempting to make the mistake of selecting answer B as being correct. The answer says '.failure of an EFIS display' which implies the loss of one of the two displays not the loss of both. EFIS displays are selectable so the primary flight display (PFD) can be switched to the screen that's still working. Remember that EASA LO 022.13.03.01.03 stated the need for standby instruments in the event of all the display units failing! Another reason for having standby instruments is in case of failure of the source of information supplied to the EFIS system. Incorrect information fed from the pitot/static system, air data computer or inertial reference unit will result in erroneous information being processed and displayed on the EFIS displays. Electronic standby instruments use independent sources so they can be used to verify the information being displayed on the EFIS displays.

Enhanced Vision System (EVS) is a technology which incorporates information from aircraft based sensors (e.g., near-infrared cameras, millimeter wave radar) to provide vision in limited visibility environments. The pilot sees the image on a dedicated display or on the background of a Primary Flight Display (PFD) or the Head-Up Display (HUD). It shows contours of terrain, the runway and its lights and possibly other objects according to their reflective properties. Its principle of operation is based on detecting wavelengths in the thermal range, i.e. it senses different temperatures rather than visible light.

During the flight, the co-pilot observes that the upper display indicates 900 kg of remaining fuel in the left tank, while the right tank still holds approximately 2500 kg of fuel. What should the crew do in this situation?

options.B: The crew should promptly open the crossfeed valve to redistribute the fuel.

Whenever there is an unexpected fuel quantity indication, a message related to fuel in the FMC or engine display, or an imbalance condition arises, it's essential to consider the possibility of a fuel leak
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: Based on student feedback, the official question includes an attachment illustrating the conditions mentioned in the question text. However, we have not yet obtained access to this official attachment. Whenever there is an unexpected fuel quantity indication, a message related to fuel in the FMC or engine display, or an imbalance condition arises, it's essential to consider the possibility of a fuel leak. Detecting a fuel leak can be aided by maintaining a fuel log and comparing the actual fuel burn to the planned fuel burn as part of the flight. It's important to note that there is no specific onboard warning for a fuel leak; it must be identified through changes or discrepancies in expected fuel consumption. Before engaging in any crossfeeding operations, it's crucial to ascertain that a fuel leak is not the root cause of the issue, as it could lead to total fuel loss. Pay close attention to parameters such as fuel flow, fuel usage, and total fuel quantity indications before deactivating any pump switches. If there is suspicion of an inflight fuel leak, take the following steps: turn off the fuel pumps for the center wing tank and close the crossfeed valve. Monitor the fuel tank quantity for any unusual drops and be alert to signs of a fuel imbalance, as these indicators can help confirm the presence of an engine fuel leak. Once an engine fuel leak is confirmed, either through visual observation or flight deck indications, it's imperative to shut down the affected engine to halt the leak and preserve the remaining fuel. After shutting down the affected engine, resume normal fuel management procedures. All remaining fuel can be utilized to power the operational engine safely.

content.question: What are the primary limitations of the Synthetic Vision System (SVS)?

options.A: The terrain is created from a database that needs to be updated regularly and there’s a risk of CFIT in case of reduced aircraft position accuracy.
options.B: The terrain is created based on live satellite information sent through an adaptor that discharges very quickly.
options.C: The SVS computer increases the overall mass of the aircraft, thus the fuel consumption.
options.D: The SVS is not yet on point as it gives a limited amount of information to the pilots.

key_points: Learning Objectives 022
learning.explanation: Learning Objectives 022.13.07.01.05: Describe the principle of SVS: an enhanced database used as reference to provide terrain and ground features to be shown on the PFD; limitations due to being a synthetic image not based on actual sensory information thus not lowering landing minima; implications if aircraft position accuracy becomes reduced. Synthetic vision systems (SVS) project an animated image of the terrain and ground features on the background of the primary flight display. This enhances the perception of attitude from the usual blue and brown air/ground symbology to an illustrative image of the surrounding terrain, obstacles, water and land, thus creating a seemingly realistic view of the aircraft’s position even in IMC. SVS constructs a representation of the external environment by merging an improved digital terrain database with an obstruction overlay database. It generates a synthetic view solely relying on this dataset, devoid of any real sensor input or external data input. The entire image is generated from a database, thus necessitating regular updates. However, these updates may not encompass temporary obstacles like cranes near airports. Furthermore, the virtual image is constructed based on the aircraft's reported position. If this position is inaccurate, the image aligns with the terrain stored in the database for the calculated position, rather than the actual terrain.

key_points: Airborne Weather Radar is a type of radar used to provide an indication to pilots of the intensity of convective weather
Modern weather radars are mostly doppler radars, capable of detecting the motion of rain droplets in addition to intensity of the precipitation
Typically, the radar antenna is located in the nose of the aircraft
learning.explanation: Airborne Weather Radar is a type of radar used to provide an indication to pilots of the intensity of convective weather. Modern weather radars are mostly doppler radars, capable of detecting the motion of rain droplets in addition to intensity of the precipitation. Typically, the radar antenna is located in the nose of the aircraft. Signals from the antenna are processed by a computer and presented on a screen which may be viewed by the pilots. Droplet size is a good indicator of strong updrafts within cumulonimbus clouds, and associated turbulence, and is indicated on the screen by patterns, colour coded for intensity. It needs to be noted that the frequency band of the radio waves (X band) is selected not to detect any cloud, small precipitation such as drizzle, fog or wind, as the droplets are too little or don’t exist. Some airborne weather radar systems may also be able to predict the presence of wind shear. *Green: light precipitation *Yellow (or amber): medium precipitation *Red: heavy precipitation *Magenta: Extremely high precipitation Radar Mode: Weather only Mode (WX) Weather + Turbulent Mode( WX+T): The areas which have strong turbulence will be showing in magenta on the display. This area is formerly showed in green on WX only Mode. Note: In an EFIS the MFD (multi-function display) displays navigational and weather information from multiple systems. MFDs are most frequently designed as "chart-centric", where the aircrew can overlay different information over a map or chart. Examples of MFD overlay information include the aircraft's current route plan, weather information from either on-board radar or lightning detection sensors or ground-based sensors, e.g., NEXRAD, restricted airspace and aircraft traffic

learning.explanation: ECAM = Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitoring (AIRBUS specific). It performs three main functions: Data acquisition and concentration Data warning computation Warning announcement and data display. The whole ECAM system is composed of several subsystems, each performing specific tasks: SDACs – System Data Acquisition Concentrators that acquire aircraft systems malfunction/failures to send them to the FWCs for generation of the corresponding alert and procedure messages. key_points: The Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitor (ECAM) is the Airbus version of an enhanced Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) system and it is used for monitoring and displaying engine and aircraft system information to the pilots
In the event of a system malfunction, it will display the fault and may also display the appropriate steps of the remedial action

learning.explanation: The Electronic Centralized Aircraft Monitor (ECAM) is the Airbus version of an enhanced Engine Indicating and Crew Alerting System (EICAS) system and it is used for monitoring and displaying engine and aircraft system information to the pilots. In the event of a system malfunction, it will display the fault and may also display the appropriate steps of the remedial action. The ECAM has two display units: ‐ One for the engine/warning display (E/WD). ‐ One for the system/status display (SD). When an abnormal situation is detected by the flight crew, the first priority of the flight crew is to maintain a safe flight path before the flight crew performs any READ & DO actions. When the flight crew performs a “READ & DO" ECAM procedure, they must: ‐ Correctly read and apply the ECAM actions ‐ Appropriately share tasks ‐ Carefully monitor and crosscheck. In flight, the PF and PM must crosscheck before any action on the following controls: ‐ ENG MASTER lever ‐ IR MODE selector ‐ All guarded controls ‐ Cockpit C/B s. The flight crew must crosscheck the above-listed controls, in order to prevent any inadvertent action by the flight crew with irreversible effects (e.g. when the flight crew operates red guarded controls).

Some questions will ask you to determine the mode selected on a given ND. To do so you need to ask yourself two questions: Is it a Full-Rose (360° compass rose displayed) or an Expanded Mode (90° of the compass rose displayed with ±45° either side of the centerline)? Is it a VOR/ILS mode or a NAV mode? The VOR/ILS mode will simply have the VOR or ILS transmitter frequency, course, and deviation scales displayed on the top right-hand corner of the ND, whereas the NAV mode will only display the TO waypoint, the distance, and the time to that waypoint.

content.question:
After a failure, whats is an appropriate procedure in the correct order for following an on-screen checklist?
1. Confirm the failure
2. Check the status of the FWS
3. Follow the checklist slowly and methodically
4. Seek confirmation prior to manipulating any guarded switches
5. Assess the possible implications of making certain selections

learning.explanation: 022.13.04.01.09: Describe an appropriate procedure for following an on-screen checklist associated with a failure scenario including the following: confirm the failure with the other flight crew member prior to performing any of the actions; seek confirmation prior to manipulating any guarded switches or thrust levers; follow the checklist slowly and methodically; assess the possible implications of making certain selections, such as opening the fuel cross-feed if there is a fuel leak even though the electronic checklist may ask for the action. For many malfunctions, an on-screen checklist will be displayed providing the pilots with recommended actions to cope with the associated loss of function. This option reduces workload and consequently stress in abnormal situations by displaying the applicable checklists to the pilots, while at the same time monitoring the correct execution of the procedures. However, such actions should be executed with thought. Pilots are required to always maintain awareness of the consequences of the actions commanded by an automated checklist. The avoid drawbacks while following on-screen checklists, the pilots should confirm the failure with the other flight crew member prior to performing any of the actions. After the malfunction is confirmed, the on-screen checklist should be followed slowly and methodically, always considering the implications of making certain selections, such as opening the fuel cross-feed if there is a fuel leak even though the electronic checklist may ask for the action. Special caution should be taken and explicit confirmation from the other crew member should always be sought when performing highly critical steps such as operating the thrust levers or any guarded switches.

The system allows for a reduced pilot workload during more operationally demanding phases of flight like take-ff, approach and landing

learning.explanation: SYNTHETIC VISION SYSTEM (SVS) A Synthetic Vision System (SVS) is an aircraft installation that combines three-dimensional data into intuitive displays to improve flight crew situational awareness. The system allows for a reduced pilot workload during more operationally demanding phases of flight like take-ff, approach and landing. SVS merges a high resolution display with terrain and obstacle databases, aeronautical information, data feeds from other aircraft, and GPS to be shown on the PFD. SVS displays a model of the real world, presenting information to the flight crew in a way that is easy to understand and rapidly assimilated. The picture presented on the SVS display(s) replaces conventional sky and ground depiction to include a 3D representation of the external environment with details of the terrain, obstacles, weather, the approach path, runway and aerodrome manoeuvring areas, and other traffic.

Some questions will ask you to determine the mode selected on a given ND. options.C: An Autophase bus.
options.D: A Serial bus.

key_points: A bus is a system for data transfer between several participants via a common transfer path
During data transfer between two participants, all others must remain silent so as not to jam each other

A serial bus can be defined as a transmission path (shared channel) over which the participants transmit their data serially in other words bit after bit, sequentially in time and using a common medium, for example, ethernet uses a serial bus architecture
learning.explanation: A bus is a system for data transfer between several participants via a common transfer path. During data transfer between two participants, all others must remain silent so as not to jam each other. A serial bus can be defined as a transmission path (shared channel) over which the participants transmit their data serially in other words bit after bit, sequentially in time and using a common medium, for example, ethernet uses a serial bus architecture. In contrast, in parallel bus systems, the individual bits which form a character are transmitted simultaneously by a certain number of data lines. This results in increased costs for cable and connectors; the transmission time is shorter than with a serial bus. Modern computer buses can use both parallel and bit serial connections.

content.question: For internal communication with the memory, the CPU makes use of…

options.C: four buses: two serial- and two parallel buses.

key_points: A computer is a machine for manipulating data according to a list of instructions
It consists of the hardware – the physical components, and the software – a variety of programs

The CPU is the brain of a computer and it usually consists of: An Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU) – performing basic arithmetical and logical operations, A control and timing unit – ensuring sequencing and coordination of operations, Memory – that is small and uses high speed that temporarily stores and controls information
learning.explanation: A computer is a machine for manipulating data according to a list of instructions. It consists of the hardware – the physical components, and the software – a variety of programs. The CPU is the brain of a computer and it usually consists of: An Arithmetic and Logic Unit (ALU) – performing basic arithmetical and logical operations, A control and timing unit – ensuring sequencing and coordination of operations, Memory – that is small and uses high speed that temporarily stores and controls information. The memory is composed of registers that are often only 32 bits. The CPU executes various programs by following the programmed instructions which are first examined and then executed in a sequential manner. It uses three buses for its internal communications with its built-in memory: one address bus, one data bus, and one control bus. When multiple tasks share common resources, such as the same CPU, it can be defined as” multitasking”. Multitasking gives the appearance of running several programs at the same time as the CPU switches rapidly between each program in turn. When two or more CPUs are used with a single computer, the operation is called “multiprocessing”. It is a hardware solution which main advantage is that it the computer’s speed will be greatly increased as it will be able to process larger amounts of information.

learning.explanation: COMPUTER A device or set of devices that can store data and a program that operates on the data. key_points: DIRECTIVE FORCE The force tending to cause the directive element of a compass to line up with the reference direction
The horizontal component of earth's magnetic field is known as the "Directive Force", which aligns the compass needle
A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field
learning.explanation: DIRECTIVE FORCE The force tending to cause the directive element of a compass to line up with the reference direction. The horizontal component of earth's magnetic field is known as the "Directive Force", which aligns the compass needle. A freely suspended magnet will align itself with the Earth's magnetic field. The total field (T) is resolved into a horizontal component (H) and a vertical component (Z). HORIZONTAL COMPONENT The horizontal component is the part which is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. A compass is freely suspended in the horizontal plane and the needle will align itself with the Earth's horizontal component (H) of the Earth's magnetic field. The compass is ineffective near the poles. As you approach the poles, the angle between magnetic flux and the horizon becomes vertical – compass ‘dip’ becomes a factor => decrease in horizontal magnetic field, increase in vertical magnetic field. The value of the horizontal component is maximum at the Magnetic Equator, a freely suspended compass needle in the Earth's magnetic field will be horizontal to the Earth - in line with the horizontal component.

key_points: The operating principles of direct reading compasses are based on the fundamentals of magnetism, in particular the interaction between the magnetic field of a suitably suspended magnetic element, and the Earth’s magnetic field

learning.explanation: The operating principles of direct reading compasses are based on the fundamentals of magnetism, in particular the interaction between the magnetic field of a suitably suspended magnetic element, and the Earth’s magnetic field. The three principle properties of a simple permanent bar magnet are that: - It attracts other pieces of iron and steel. - Its power of attraction is concentrated at each end of the bar. - When suspended to move horizontally, it always comes to rest in an approximately north - south direction. Magnetism is concentrated at a magnet's extremities, called poles. Therefore, statement 2 is correct. Additionally, a freely suspended magnetised rod always aligns itself approximately in a north-south orientation. The end that seeks north is called the north seeking or red pole, and the end that seeks south, is called the south seeking or blue pole. A unit pole cannot exist. If a magnet is cut into two pieces, each piece will have two poles. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect.

content.question: In a gyromagnetic compass, the flux valve feeds the…

options.A: erecting system.
options.B: heading indicator.
options.C: amplifier.

key_points: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope
The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors
The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro
learning.explanation: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

content.question: A pilot wishes to turn left on to a northerly heading with 10° bank at a latitude of 50° North. Using a direct reading compass, in order to achieve this he must stop the turn on an approximate heading of…

key_points: Step 1: Find the direction of the turn – clockwise or anticlockwise? The aircraft turns to the left onto a northerly heading => anticlockwise
Step 2: Use the acronym ‘UNOS’ to find if you will overshoot or undershoot? UN – Undershoot = apparent turn to the North
OS – Overshoot = apparent turn to the South
learning.explanation: Step 1: Find the direction of the turn – clockwise or anticlockwise? The aircraft turns to the left onto a northerly heading => anticlockwise. Step 2: Use the acronym ‘UNOS’ to find if you will overshoot or undershoot? UN – Undershoot = apparent turn to the North. OS – Overshoot = apparent turn to the South. By banking in an anticlockwise direction to 000° (northerly heading), you will need to undershoot by a certain amount if you want to stop your turn exactly at 000°. Step 3: Find the angle by which you will need to overshoot/undershoot by using the following formula (Refer to diagram 1): (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 2 Remember that the turning error is greatest on a Northerly/Southerly heading. Therefore any time you turn through the North or South the error will be the highest, and any time you turn through West or East the error will be the smallest. Consequently, when your heading is between North and East or South and East, etc. (half-way between two cardinal points) the turning error will be only half as big or twice as big as at these headings. Only in this case, you will use the following formula (Refer to diagram 2) : (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 4 In this question, the aircraft turns to the left onto heading 000°, so it’s turning from an easterly heading (no error) onto a northerly heading (biggest error). As we are not turning on a heading that is midway between two cardinal points, there is no need to apply the second formula. Therefore, you will need to overshoot the heading by: (Bank angle + Lat) ÷ 2 = (10 + 50) ÷ 2 = 30° Step 4: Add/subtract the angle found in step 3 to find the angle at which you should stop the turn so that the compass indicated the desired heading: The desired heading is 000°, and in order to stop the turn at 000°, you need to undershoot this heading by 30°:000 + 30 = 030° Note: We are adding here because undershooting 000° means stopping the turn before passing this value on your compass. Since you turn anticlockwise, the heading values decrease, so you need to add the angle found in step 3 to find the correct undershooting angle.

The extreme ends of the magnet represent the areas where most of the magnetic field lines are concentrated and are referred to as its magnetic poles
By definition, the pole where field lines exit the body is called its north pole, and the pole where they re-enter the material is called its south pole
learning.explanation: A magnet is a body that attracts or repels other magnetisable bodies depending on the magnetic moment of their elementary particles, obtained through their spin. The extreme ends of the magnet represent the areas where most of the magnetic field lines are concentrated and are referred to as its magnetic poles. By definition, the pole where field lines exit the body is called its north pole, and the pole where they re-enter the material is called its south pole. A magnetic body that is placed in a foreign magnetic field always aligns itself in a specific way; opposing poles attract one another, whereas identical poles repel each other. A freely suspended magnet always rests in the north-south direction because the magnetic south pole of the earth lies in the geographic north direction and the magnetic north pole of the earth lies in the geographical south direction.

content.question: The charted values of magnetic variation on Earth normally change annually due to…

options.A: an increasing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to increase.
options.B: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase or decrease.
options.C: a reducing field strength causing numerical values at all locations to decrease.
options.D: magnetic pole movement causing numerical values at all locations to increase.

key_points: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole
The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North
Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction
learning.explanation: The magnetic variation is caused by the different locations of the geographic (true) North Pole and the magnetic North Pole. The horizontal component of the Earth’s magnetic field is the part that is detected by the compass needle in order to determine Magnetic North. Therefore, it is accurate enough to say that variation is the angle between the horizontal component of the magnetic field and the true north direction. At a specific location, the value of magnetic variation varies slowly over time. In fact, the magnetic pole is constantly moving, causing the values at all locations to increase or decrease. This periodic change is also reflected in the slow movement of the magnetic poles monitored through the various ground and satellite-based stations/instruments. The IRS of the aircraft also contains a variation program. It is supplied to the IRS true North to obtain a magnetic heading, which is ultimately fed to the FMS. The IRS is also normally recalibrated from time to time so that it can maintain the variation accurately enough. Lately, the magnetic pole location is changing more rapidly, approximately at a rate of 30 to 40 miles per year, moving towards Siberia. The need to continuously monitor and update the magnetic variation charts is, therefore, more crucial than ever.

learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. key_points: The pendulous magnet inside the direct reading magnetic compass will align itself with the magnetic flux lines of the Earth’s magnetic field

learning.explanation: The pendulous magnet inside the direct reading magnetic compass will align itself with the magnetic flux lines of the Earth’s magnetic field. They’re straight and horizontal close to the Equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical, as the compass approaches the pole. content.question: The location of the Earth`s magnetic poles…

options.A: is the same as the geographical poles.
options.B: periodically wander (as much as 15 km every year).
options.C: is static in time with respect to the geographical poles.
options.D: is static in time.

key_points: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen
Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another
These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass
learning.explanation: The Earth has a magnetic field that has the same properties as any other simple magnet you may have seen. Because of this, the Earth’s magnetic field consists of magnetic field lines flowing from one pole to another. These lines have some properties that are very important to understand as they greatly affect our navigation on Earth and thus, our navigation instruments such as the magnetic compass. In fact, these magnetic lines are not straight lines spread equally around the Earth. They are straight and horizontal close to the equator, but the higher the latitude, the more these lines tend to converge towards the Earth’s poles. Therefore, they will become more and more inclined until being fully vertical at the pole. As a consequence, the pendulous magnet will also increasingly tilt towards its vertical and produce greater instrument errors (turning, acceleration…). The magnetic lines converge at the magnetic poles, which is different from the geographic pole (the axis around which the Earth is spinning). Another to consider is that the magnetic poles continuously change location. For instance, right now the magnetic North pole is situated approximately in Northern Canada, but it is moving at a rate of about 50km/year towards Siberia. On the other hand, the South magnetic pole is moving at around 15 km/year, the same rate at which the North magnetic pole used to move as well as a few years ago.

key_points: Compass swing is the process of assessing deviation caused by various factors like magnetic materials, electrical currents, and the airframe

The goals of a compass swing are to identify deviations between magnetic north (observed on a landing compass) and compass north (observed in the aircraft) across various headings; correct / remove as much deviation as possible and document the remaining residual deviation post-adjustment
Occasions for Swinging the Compass When compass components are installed or replaced
learning.explanation: Compass swing is the process of assessing deviation caused by various factors like magnetic materials, electrical currents, and the airframe. The goals of a compass swing are to identify deviations between magnetic north (observed on a landing compass) and compass north (observed in the aircraft) across various headings; correct / remove as much deviation as possible and document the remaining residual deviation post-adjustment. Occasions for Swinging the Compass When compass components are installed or replaced. Whenever the accuracy of the compass is in doubt. After a maintenance inspection if required by the placarded schedule. After a significant aircraft modification, repair or replacement involving magnetic material. options.B: sense the strength and direction of magnetic fields.
options.C: measure the phase of an AC generator.

key_points: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope
The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors
The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro
learning.explanation: The gyromagnetic compass is the combination of a simple compass and a gyroscope. The indications of the magnetic compass are stabilized by the gyroscope to reduce the effects of acceleration and turning errors. The main components of a gyromagnetic compass are the flux valve, the heading indicator, the slaving amplifier, the synchronizing motor, and the horizontal gyro. The flux valve (=flux detection unit) senses the Earth’s magnetic field which is compared to the position of the drive shaft connecting the horizontal gyro and the heading indicator. Anytime the gyro has drifted, and its position would differ from the flux valve field, an AC error signal is transmitted to the precession amplifier. Before being converted into a DC signal, the AC signal is first amplified, and phase detected. This signal drives the precession motor that will realign the gyro. The new position is compared again, and the synchronization will continue until the heading indicator is synchronized. The flux valve is usually remotely located in the wingtip or the fin of the aircraft to be free of any magnetic disturbances. An easy way to remember the order of the gyromagnetic compass operation is by using the acronym ‘FEAT’: Flux valve => Error detector => Amplifier => Torque motor

learning.explanation: The compass is subject to acceleration/deceleration and turning errors. Therefore, you can only have a precise indication in straight and level flight. The magnet inside the compass is a pendulous system and is attached to the aircraft at the pivot point. When the aircraft accelerates on a westerly/easterly heading, the magnet will lag behind due to its inertia as the acceleration will act on the magnet’s center of gravity. Therefore, it will momentarily indicate a turn and the heading indication will erroneously change. There will be no error when accelerating/decelerating in a southerly/northerly direction as this will take place in the direction of the Earth’s magnetic flux lines. An easy way to remember the acceleration errors is by using the acronym ‘ANDS’: AN – Accelerate = apparent turn to the North. DS – Decelerate = apparent turn to the South. The magnet inside the compass case is always ‘North seeking’, so it will always remain in a steady position.
